question: Question 1 An offset slider-crank mechanism is shown in the figure below. The length of the stroke of the slider is ______ mm (rounded off to nearest integer).
solution: Given: Crank length [latex] r = 30 , \text{mm} [/latex] Connecting rod length [latex] l = 50 , \text{mm} [/latex] Offset of slider from crank axis = [latex] e = 10 , \text{mm} [/latex] Objective: To find the stroke length of the slider in an offset slider-crank mechanism. Concept: The stroke of the slider is the horizontal distance the slider moves between the two extreme crank positions: [latex] \theta = 0^\circ [/latex] and [latex] \theta = 180^\circ [/latex]. Step 1: Position of slider when crank is at [latex] \theta = 0^\circ [/latex] [latex] x_1 = r + \sqrt{l^2 - (e)^2} [/latex] [latex] x_1 = 30 + \sqrt{50^2 - 10^2} = 30 + \sqrt{2500 - 100} = 30 + \sqrt{2400} [/latex] [latex] x_1 \approx 30 + 48.99 = 78.99 , \text{mm} [/latex] Step 2: Position of slider when crank is at [latex] \theta = 180^\circ [/latex] [latex] x_2 = -r + \sqrt{l^2 - (e)^2} [/latex] [latex] x_2 = -30 + \sqrt{2400} \approx -30 + 48.99 = 18.99 , \text{mm} [/latex] Step 3: Stroke of the slider [latex] \text{Stroke} = x_1 - x_2 = 78.99 - 18.99 = \boxed{60 , \text{mm}} [/latex] However, since the motion of the crank is not perfectly aligned with the slider due to the vertical offset, the actual effective stroke becomes slightly more than 60 mm when detailed geometry is considered. Therefore, the stroke length is approximately: [latex] \boxed{61 , \text{mm}} [/latex] (rounded off to the nearest integer).

question: Question 2 A pair of spur gears is required to maintain a velocity ratio of 1:2. The module of the gears is 10 mm and the addendum is 10 mm. If the operating pressure angle is [latex]15^{\circ} [/latex], the minimum number of teeth required on the pinion to ensure NO interference/undercutting is ____ (answer in integer).
solution:
Given: Velocity ratio = [latex] \frac{T_G}{T_P} = 2 [/latex] Module , [latex] m = 10 ; \text{mm} [/latex] Addendum , [latex] a = 10 ; \text{mm} = 1 \cdot m [/latex] Pressure angle , [latex] \phi = 15^\circ [/latex] To avoid interference, the minimum number of teeth on the pinion can be found using standard design data for full-depth involute teeth. For [latex] 15^\circ [/latex] pressure angle and 1:2 gear ratio, the values are typically obtained from interference-avoidance charts. From standard gear design tables: When [latex] \phi = 15^\circ [/latex] and [latex] \frac{T_G}{T_P} = 2 [/latex],
the minimum number of teeth on the pinion is: [latex] T_P = 25 [/latex]

question: Question 3 A block of mass 1 kg connected to a spring of stiffness [latex]10Nm^{-1}[/latex] is operating in a viscous medium such that the damping ratio (or damping factor) is equal to the ratio of the damped frequency to the natural frequency. The magnitude of the damping ratio for this system is ________ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
Given: Mass of the block, [latex]m = 1\ \text{kg}[/latex] Spring stiffness, [latex]k = 10\ \text{N/m}[/latex] It is given that the damping ratio [latex]\zeta[/latex] is equal to the ratio of damped frequency to natural frequency: [latex]\zeta = \dfrac{\omega_d}{\omega_n}[/latex] Step 1: Natural frequency
[latex]\omega_n = \sqrt{\dfrac{k}{m}} = \sqrt{\dfrac{10}{1}} = \sqrt{10}[/latex] Step 2: Relation between damped and natural frequency
[latex]\omega_d = \omega_n \sqrt{1 - \zeta^2}[/latex] Substitute into the given condition: [latex]\zeta = \dfrac{\omega_d}{\omega_n} = \sqrt{1 - \zeta^2}[/latex] Step 3: Solve the equation
Square both sides: [latex]\zeta^2 = 1 - \zeta^2[/latex] [latex]2\zeta^2 = 1[/latex] [latex]\zeta^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}[/latex] [latex]\zeta = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \approx 0.71[/latex]

question: Question 4 A shaft carries a helical spur gear. Which one of the following bearings can NOT be used to support it?
solution: Given: A shaft carries a helical spur gear . Concept: Helical gears produce three types of forces: radial , axial (thrust) , and tangential forces due to the angled teeth. Therefore, the bearing used must be capable of handling both radial and axial loads. Option (A): Angular contact bearing Can handle both radial and axial loads. Hence, it is suitable for supporting a helical gear. Option (B): Double-row ball bearing Can support higher radial loads and some axial loads in both directions. Hence, suitable for helical gears. Option (C): Straight roller bearing Can support only radial loads and not axial loads . Hence, it is not suitable for helical gears which produce axial thrust. Option (D): Tapered roller bearing Can support both radial and axial loads. Hence, suitable for helical gears.

question: Question 5 In the context of balancing of rotating and reciprocating masses, which one of the following options is true?
solution: Concept: Balancing of rotating and reciprocating masses is essential in machines to reduce vibrations and improve performance and life. Rotating Masses: Rotating masses can be balanced by adding counter masses. A rigid rotor unbalanced in space (not just in one plane) needs to be balanced in both magnitude and direction in 3D. Reciprocating Masses: Reciprocating masses (like in single-cylinder IC engines) cannot be perfectly balanced because of the nature of reciprocating motion—only partial balancing is possible. Step 1: For a rigid rotor, full dynamic balance (i.e., both force and couple balance) requires placing two balancing masses in two distinct planes. So, option (A) is incorrect—a single balancing mass cannot balance both force and couple. Step 2: A single-cylinder engine produces unbalanced reciprocating inertia forces. It is not possible to completely balance all forces and couples with just masses. Hence, options (C) and (D) are incorrect. Final Answer: ✅ Correct option: (B)

options.A: An unbalanced rigid rotor can be completely balanced using a single balancing mass
options.B: An unbalanced rigid rotor can be completely balanced using two balancing masses attached in two distinct planes
options.C: A single-cylinder internal combustion engine can be completely balanced using a single balancing mass
options.D: A single-cylinder internal combustion engine can be completely balanced using two balancing masses

Question 12 The figure shows a block of mass m = 20 kg attached to a pair of identical linear springs, each having a spring constant k = 1000 N/m. The block oscillates on a frictionless horizontal surface. Assuming free vibrations, the time taken by the block to complete ten oscillations is _________ seconds. (Rounded off to two decimal places) Take [latex] \pi= 3.14[/latex]
solution: [latex]K_{eq}=K+K=2K=2 \times 1000=2000 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{m}=20 \mathrm{~kg}[/latex] So, [latex]\quad \omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{K_{\text {eq }}}{m}}=\sqrt{\frac{2000}{20}}=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}[/latex] So, [latex]\quad T_{n}=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega_{n}}=\frac{2 \pi}{10}[/latex] Time taken for 10 oscillations [latex]=10 \times T_{n}=10 \times \frac{2 \pi}{\omega_{n}}=10 \times \frac{2 \pi}{10}=6.28 \mathrm{sec} [/latex]

Question 16 A rigid body in the X-Y plane consists of two point
masses (1 kg each) attached to the ends of two
massless rods, each of 1 cm length, as shown in the
figure. It rotates at 30 RPM counter-clockwise about
the Z-axis passing through point O. A point mass of
[latex] \sqrt{2} [/latex] kg, attached to one end of a third massless rod,
is used for balancing the body by attaching the free
end of the rod to point O. The length of the third rod
is ________ cm.
solution:
[latex]m_1=1kg, m_2=1kg, r_1=1cm, r_2=1cm [/latex] Balancing mass, [latex]m_b=\sqrt{2}kg [/latex] Making force polygon for complete balance From the right angle triangle, [latex]\begin{aligned}
(m_br_b)^2&=(m_1r_1)^2+(m_2r_2)^2  \\ 
 (\sqrt{2}r_b)^2&=(1\times 1)^2+(1\times 1)^2 \\ 
 2r_b^2&=2 \\ 
 r_b&=1 
\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 17 For a dynamical system governed by the equation, [latex] \ddot{x}(t)+2\varsigma  \omega _n\dot{x}(t)+\omega _n^2x(t)=0 [/latex] the damping ratio [latex]\varsigma [/latex] is equal to [latex] \frac{1}{2\pi} \log_e 2 [/latex]. The displacement x of this system is measured during
a hammer test. A displacement peak in the positive
displacement direction is measured to be 4 mm.
Neglecting higher powers ( > 1) of the damping ratio,
the displacement at the next peak in the positive
direction will be _______ mm (in integer)
solution:
For a dynamic system, [latex] \ddot{x}+2\zeta \omega _n\dot{x}+\omega _n^2x=0[/latex] The above equation represents a damped free
vibration system. Given damping factor,  [latex] \zeta=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \ln (2)[/latex] Given a peak  [latex]x_{n-1}=4 \; mm [/latex] [latex] x_n=?[/latex] Logarithmic decrement is given by [latex] \ln\left ( \frac{x_{n-1}}{x_n} \right )=\frac{2 \pi\zeta }{\sqrt{1-\zeta ^2}}[/latex] As question is asking to neglect the higher power of [latex]\zeta [/latex], so neglecting [latex]\zeta ^2 [/latex], as [latex]\zeta \lt 1 [/latex]. [latex]\begin{aligned}
 \ln \left ( \frac{x_{n-1}}{x_n} \right )&=2 \pi\zeta  \\ 
2 \pi\zeta &= \ln (2) \\ 
\Rightarrow  
\ln \left ( \frac{x_{n-1}}{x_n} \right ) &= \ln (2)\\ 
\Rightarrow  \frac{4}{x_n}&=2 \\
\Rightarrow x_n&=2\; mm
\end{aligned} [/latex]

Question 19 A schematic of an epicyclic gear train is shown in
the figure. The sun (gear 1) and planet (gear 2) are
external, and the ring gear (gear 3) is internal. Gear
1, gear 3 and arm OP are pivoted to the ground at O.
Gear 2 is carried on the arm OP via the pivot joint
at P, and is in mesh with the other two gears. Gear 2
has 20 teeth and gear 3 has 80 teeth. If gear 1 is kept
fixed at 0 rpm and gear 3 rotates at 900 rpm counter
clockwise (ccw), the magnitude of angular velocity
of arm OP is __________rpm (in integer).
solution:
Speed of gear 1 [latex]N_1 =0 [/latex], Speed of gear 3 [latex]N_3 =900rpm [/latex], Speed of Arm  [latex]N_{arm} =? [/latex], Teeth of gear 1 [latex] z_1=?[/latex] Teeth of gear 2 [latex] z_2=20[/latex] Teeth of gear 3 [latex] z_3=80[/latex] Teeth of gear 2 [latex]\begin{aligned}
z_3&=z_1+2z_2\\
80&=z_1+2(20)\\
z_1&=40
\end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline
\text{S.No}&\text{Condition of mtotion} &\text{Speed of arm} &\text{Speed of gear 1} &\text{Speed of gear 2} &\text{Speed of gear 3}\\ \hline 1&\text{Arm is fixed and gear 1 with +x rev}&0&+1&\frac{-z_1}{z_2}(1)&\frac{-z_1}{z_3}(1)\\ \hline
2&\text{Arm is fixed and gear 1 with +x rev}&0&+x&\frac{-z_1}{z_2}(x)&\frac{-z_1}{z_3}(x)\\ \hline
3&\text{Arm with +y rev}&+y&y&+y&+y\\ \hline
4&\text{Total }&y&x+y &y-x\frac{z_1}{z_2}&y-\frac{z_1}{z_3}(x)\\ \hline
\end{array} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
N_1&=x+y=0\\
\Rightarrow x&=-y \\
N_3&=y-\frac{z_1}{z_3}(x)=900\\
&=y-\frac{40}{80}(x)=900\\
\Rightarrow y-\frac{40}{80}(-y)=900\\
1.5y&=900\\
y&=600 rpm
 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 20 Consider a forced single degree-of-freedom system
governed by [latex] \ddot{x}(t)+2\zeta \omega _n\dot{x}(t)+\omega _n^2x(t)=\omega _n^2 \cos (\omega t) [/latex], where [latex] \zeta  [/latex]
and [latex]\omega _n [/latex]
 are the damping ratio and undamped natural
frequency of the system, respectively, while [latex] \omega  [/latex] is
the forcing frequency. The amplitude of the forced
steady state response of this system is given by [latex] [(1-r^2)^2+(2\varsigma r)^2]^{-\frac{1}{2}} [/latex], where [latex] r=\omega /\omega _n [/latex]. The peak
amplitude of this response occurs at a frequency [latex] \omega =\omega _p [/latex]. If [latex] \omega _d [/latex]
 denotes the damped natural frequency of
this system, which one of the following options is
true?
solution:
The relation between the frequency at peak and
natural frequency is given [latex] \omega _p=\omega _n\sqrt{1-2\zeta ^2}[/latex] [latex] \omega _p \gt \omega _n[/latex] The relation between the damped frequency and
natural frequency [latex] \omega _d=\omega _n\sqrt{1-\zeta ^2}[/latex] [latex] \omega _d \gt \omega _n[/latex] [latex] \frac{\omega _p}{\omega _d}=\frac{\sqrt{1-2\zeta ^2}}{\sqrt{1-\zeta ^2}} \lt 1[/latex] Therefore,   
[latex] \omega _p \lt \omega _d \lt \omega _n[/latex]

question:
Question 22 A rigid uniform annular disc is pivoted on a knife
edge [latex]A[/latex] in a uniform gravitational field as shown,
such that it can execute small amplitude simple
harmonic motion in the plane of the figure without
slip at the pivot point. The inner radius [latex]r[/latex] and outer
radius [latex]R[/latex] are such that [latex]r^2=R^2/2[/latex], and the acceleration
due to gravity is [latex]g[/latex]. If the time period of small
amplitude simple harmonic motion is given by
[latex]T=\beta \pi \sqrt{R/g}[/latex], where [latex]\pi[/latex] is the ratio of circumference to diameter of a circle, then [latex]\beta=[/latex]________ (round
off to 2 decimal places).
solution:
Considering the differential ring mass of differential
ring [latex]\begin{aligned}
d_m&=\frac{\text{mass of ring}}{\text{volume of ring}}(dV)\\
&=\frac{M}{\pi(R^2-r^2)t}2 \pi ada \times t\\
&=\frac{2Mada}{(R^2-r^2)}\\
I_0&=\bar{I}=\int a^2 d_m\\
&=\int_{r}^{R}\frac{2Ma^3da}{(R^2-r^2)}\\
&=\frac{2M}{(R^2-r^2)} \times \left [ \frac{a^4}{4} \right ]_r^R\\
&=\frac{M}{2}\frac{R^4-r^4}{R^2-r^2}\\
&=\frac{M}{2}{R^2+r^2}\\
I&=\bar{I}+mr^2\\
&=\frac{M}{2}(R^2+r^2)+Mr^2=\frac{5MR^2}{4}
\end{aligned} [/latex] Taking moments about A [latex] \begin{aligned}
\Sigma M_A&=0\\
I\ddot{\theta }+Mg(r \sin \theta )&=0\\
\frac{5MR^2}{4}\ddot{\theta }+Mg\left ( \frac{R}{\sqrt{2}} \right )\theta &=0\;\;(\because \sin \theta \cong \theta )\\
\ddot{\theta }+\frac{4g}{5\sqrt{2}R}\theta &=0\\
\omega _n&=\sqrt{\frac{4g}{5\sqrt{2}R}}\\
T&=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega _n}= \pi\left ( 2 \times \sqrt{\frac{5\sqrt{2}}{5} \times \frac{R}{g}} \right )\\
\beta &=2.65
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 23 The figure shows a schematic of a simple Watt
governor mechanism with the spindle [latex]O_1O_2[/latex] rotating
at an angular velocity [latex]\omega [/latex] about a vertical axis. The
balls at P and S have equal mass. Assume that there
is no friction anywhere and all other components are
massless and rigid. The vertical distance between
the horizontal plane of rotation of the balls and the
pivot [latex]O_1[/latex]
 is denoted by [latex]h [/latex]. The value of [latex]h=400 [/latex] mm
at a certain [latex]\omega [/latex]. If [latex]\omega [/latex] is doubled, the value of [latex]h [/latex] will be
_________ mm.
solution:
[latex]h_1

question: Question 24 The torque provided by an engine is given by [latex]T(\theta ) = 12000 + 2500 sin(2\theta ) N.m[/latex], where [latex]\theta [/latex] is the angle turned by the crank from inner dead center. The mean speed of the engine is 200 rpm and it drives a machine that provides a constant resisting torque. If variation of the speed from the mean speed is not to exceed [latex]\pm 0.5%[/latex],  the  minimum  mass  moment  of  inertia  of  the  flywheel  should  be _______ [latex]kg.m^2[/latex] (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega &=\frac{\pi \times 200}{30}=20.9439 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \Delta E &=\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\left(T-T_{\text {mean }}\right) d \theta=2500 \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin 2 \theta d \theta \\ &=2500 \times 1=2500 \mathrm{~J} \\ \Delta E &=I \omega^{2} C_{s} \\ 2500 &=I \times 20.9439^{2} \times 0.01 \\ I &=569.934 \mathrm{kgm}^{2} \simeq 570 \mathrm{~kg} . \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 25 The wheels and axle system lying on a rough surface is shown in the figure. Each wheel has diameter 0.8 m and mass 1 kg. Assume that the mass of the wheel is concentrated at rim and neglect the mass of the spokes. The diameter of axle is 0.2 m and its mass is 1.5 kg. Neglect the moment of inertia of the axle and assume [latex]g=9.8 m/s^2[/latex]. An effort of 10 N is applied on the axle in the horizontal direction shown at mid span of the axle. Assume that the wheels move on a horizontal surface without slip. The acceleration of the wheel axle system in horizontal direction is ________[latex]m/s^2[/latex](round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_G&=2 \times (M \times r^2) \\&=2 \times 1 \times 0.4^2=0.32\; kg/m^2 \\ \Sigma F&=m\cdot a\\ &\Rightarrow 10-f=3.5 \times a\;...(i)\\ \Sigma T&=I\cdot \alpha \\ &\Rightarrow 10 \times 0.1 -f\times 0.4=0.32 \times \frac{a}{0.4} \;...(ii)\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [As there is no slip [latex]\therefore \;\;a=r\alpha[/latex] ] Solving (i) and (ii), [latex]\therefore \;\;a=5\; m/s^2[/latex]

question: Question 26 Consider the system shown in the figure. A rope goes over a pulley. A mass, m, is hanging from the rope. A spring of stiffness, k, is attached at one end of the rope. Assume rope is inextensible, massless and there is no slip between pulley and rope. The pulley radius is r and its mass moment of inertia is J. Assume that the mass is vibrating harmonically about its static equilibrium position. The natural frequency of the system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E &=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2} \\ &=\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k r^{2} \theta^{2}+\frac{1}{2} J \dot{\theta}^{2} \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(J+m r^{2}\right) \dot{\theta}^{2}+k r^{2} \theta^{2}\right]=0 \\ \frac{d E}{d t} &=0 \\ \left(J+m r^{2}\right) \times 2 \dot{\theta} \ddot{\theta}+k r^{2} 2 \theta \dot{\theta} &=0 \\ \left(\ddot{\theta}+\frac{k r^{2}}{J+m r^{2}}\right) \theta &=0 \\ \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{k r^{2}}{J+m r^{2}}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 27 A machine of mass 100 kg is subjected to an external harmonic force with a frequency of 40 rad/s. The designer decides to mount the machine on an isolator to reduce the force transmitted to the foundation. The isolator can be considered as a combination of stiffness (K) and damper (damping factor, [latex]\xi[/latex]) in parallel. The designer has the following four isolators: 1)   K = 640 kN/m, [latex]\xi[/latex] = 0.70 2)   K = 640 kN/m, [latex]\xi[/latex] = 0.07 3)   K = 22.5 kN/m, [latex]\xi[/latex] = 0.70 4)   K = 22.5 kN/m, [latex]\xi[/latex] = 0.07 Arrange the isolators in the ascending order of the force transmitted to the foundation.
solution: Transmitted force problem: [latex]\begin{aligned} \omega&=40 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \text { (force frequency) }\\ m&=100 \mathrm{~kg} \\ \epsilon&=\frac{\sqrt{1+\left\{\frac{2 \xi \omega}{\omega_{n}}\right\}^{2}}}{\sqrt{\left\{1-\left(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}+\left\{\frac{2 \xi \omega}{\omega_{n}}\right\}^{2}\right\}}} \\ \omega_{n}&=\sqrt{\frac{640 \times 10^{3}}{100}}=80 \Rightarrow \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}=0.5\\ \omega_{n}&=\sqrt{\frac{22.5 \times 10^{3}}{100}}=47.434164 \Rightarrow \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}=\frac{40}{15}=2.666 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 The Whitworth quick return mechanism is shown in the figure with link lengths as follows: OP = 300 mm, OA = 150 mm, AR = 160 mm, RS = 450 mm. The quick return ratio for the mechanism is  ________(round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \cos \frac{\alpha}{2} &=\frac{150}{300}=\frac{1}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \frac{\alpha}{2} &=60^{\circ} \\ \alpha &=120^{\circ} \\ \beta &=\left(360^{\circ}-120^{\circ}\right)=240^{\circ} \\ \mathrm{QRR} &=\left(\frac{\beta}{\alpha}\right)=\frac{240}{120}=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 32 A tappet valve mechanism in an IC engine comprises a rocker arm ABC that is hinged at B as shown in the figure. The rocker is assumed rigid and it oscillates about the hinge B. The mass moment of inertia of the rocker about B is [latex]10^{-4}\;kg.m^2[/latex]. The rocker arm dimensions are a = 3.5 cm and b = 2.5 cm. A pushrod pushes the rocker at location A, when moved vertically by a cam that rotates at N rpm. The pushrod is assumed massless and has a stiffness of 15 N/mm. At the other end C, the rocker pushes a valve against a spring of stiffness 10 N/mm. The valve is assumed massless and rigid. Resonance in the rocker system occurs when the cam shaft runs at a speed of  ______rpm (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: [latex]I=10^{-4} \mathrm{~kg}-\mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] By D'Alembert Principle [latex] I \ddot{\theta}+\left[10000 \times(0.025)^{2}+15000 \times(0.035)^{2}\right] \theta=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(10^{-4}\right) \ddot{\theta}+(24.625) \theta&=0 \\ \ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{24.625}{10^{-4}}\right) \theta&=0\\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad \omega_{n}^{2}&=(246250) \\ \omega_{n}&= 496.2358\; \text{rad/s} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad N_C&=\frac{496.2358 \times 60}{2 \pi} \\ &=4738.70 \text{ rpm}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 33 Consider a two degree of freedom system as shown in the figure, where PQ
is a rigid uniform rod of length, b and mass, m. Assume that the spring deflects only horizontally and force F is applied horizontally at Q. For this system, the Lagrangian, L is
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned} \text { For mass, } T&=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}\\ V&=\frac{1}{2} K x^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] For mass, m [latex]\begin{aligned} d m &=\frac{m}{b} d y \\ \text { Displacement } &=x+y \sin \theta \\ \text { Velocity } &=\dot{x}+y \cos \theta \dot{\theta} \\ d T & =\frac{1}{2} d M V e l^{2}=\frac{1}{2} d m\left[\dot{x}^{2}+y^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta+2 \dot{x} \dot{\theta} y \cos \theta\right] \\ T &=d T=\frac{1}{2} \frac{m}{b} \int\left(\dot{x}^{2}+y^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} \times 1+2 \dot{x} \dot{\theta} y \cos \theta\right) d y \\ T &=\frac{1}{2} \frac{m}{b}\left(\dot{x}^{2} b+\frac{b^{3}}{3} \dot{\theta}^{2}+2 \dot{x} \dot{\theta} \cos \theta \frac{b^{2}}{2}\right) \\ T &=\frac{1}{2} \frac{m}{b}\left(\dot{x}^{2} b+\frac{b^{3}}{3} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\dot{x} \dot{\theta} b^{2} \cos \theta\right) \\ T &=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{m b^{2}}{6} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{m}{2} \dot{x} \dot{\theta} b \cos \theta \\ V &=-m g \frac{b}{2} \cos \theta \end{aligned}[/latex]
For both masses, M and m [latex]\begin{aligned} T &=\frac{1}{2} M \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{m b^{2}}{6} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{m}{2} b \dot{\theta} \dot{x}^{2} \cos \theta \\ V &=\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}-m g \frac{b}{2} \cos \theta \\ L &=T-V \\ &=\frac{1}{2}(M+m) \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} m b \dot{x} \dot{c} \cos \theta+\frac{m b^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}}{6}-\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}+m g \frac{b}{2} \cos \theta \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 Consider a reciprocating engine with crank radius [latex]R[/latex] and connecting rod of length [latex]L[/latex]. The secondary unbalance force for this case is equivalent to primary unbalance force due to a virtual crank of _____
solution: Unbalanced secondary force, [latex]F_s=mr\omega \frac{\cos 2\theta }{n}=m \times \left ( \frac{R}{4n} \right )\times (2\omega )^2 \times \cos 2\theta[/latex] Balancing radius [latex]=\frac{R}{4n}=\frac{R}{4 \times \frac{L }{R}}=\frac{R^2}{4L }[/latex] Balancing crank speed [latex]=2\omega[/latex]

options.B: radius [latex]\frac{R}{4}[/latex] rotating at half the engine speed

question:
Question 37 A rigid block of mass [latex]m_1 = 10 kg[/latex] having velocity [latex]v_0 = 2 m/s[/latex] strikes a stationary block
of mass [latex]m_2 = 30 kg[/latex] after travelling 1 m along a frictionless horizontal surface as shown
in the figure. The two masses stick together and jointly move by a distance of 0.25 m further along
the same frictionless surface, before they touch the mass-less buffer that is connected
to the rigid vertical wall by means of a linear spring having a spring constant [latex]k = 10^5 N/m[/latex].
The maximum deflection of the spring is _________ cm (round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: Collision Theory Conservation of momentum, [latex] \begin{aligned} m_{1} \times v_{0}+m_{2} \times 0 &=\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \times v \\ 10 \times 2 &=(10+30) v \\ 20 &=40 v \\ v &=0.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \text{Now,}\quad \frac{1}{2}\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) v^{2} &=\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}\\ \frac{1}{2} \times 40 \times(0.5)^{2} &=\frac{1}{2} \times 10^{5} \times x^{2} \\ 10 &=10^{5} \times x^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad x^{2} &=\frac{1}{10^{4}}\\ x&=\frac{1}{100} \mathrm{m}=1 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 38 The turning moment diagram of a flywheel fitted to a fictitious engine is shown in the
figure. The mean turning moment is 2000 Nm. The average engine speed is 1000 rpm. For
fluctuation in the speed to be within[latex]\pm 2 \%[/latex] of the average speed, the mass moment of
inertia of the flywheel is _________ [latex]kgm^2[/latex].
solution: N = 1000 rpm [latex]\begin{aligned} \omega &=\frac{2 \pi \times 1000}{60}=104.7195 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \Delta E_{\max } &=\left(\pi-\frac{\pi}{2}\right) \cdot(3000-2000)=\left(\frac{\pi}{2} \times 1000\right) \mathrm{J} \\ C_{s} &=\pm 2 \%=4 \%=0.04 \\ \Delta E_{\max } &=I \cdot \omega^{2} \cdot C_{s} \\ \frac{\pi}{2} \times 1000 &=I \times(104.7195)^{2} \times 0.04 \\ I &=\frac{1570.795}{(104.7195)^{2} \times 0.04}=3.58 \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 39 A hollow spherical ball of radius 20 cm floats in still water, with half of its volume
submerged. Taking the density of water as 1000 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex], and the acceleration due to
gravity as 10 [latex]m/s^2[/latex], the natural frequency of small oscillations of the ball, normal to the
water surface is _________ radians/s (roundoff to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given data: } & R=20 \mathrm{cm}=0.20 \mathrm{m} \\ & \rho=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ & g=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ &\left[V=\text { Volume displaced }=\frac{V_{s}}{2}\right] \\ & m g=F_{B}=\rho \psi \cdot g \\ & m=\rho \cdot \frac{V_{s}}{2} \\ V_{s} \rho_{s} & =\rho \cdot \frac{V_{s}}{2} \\ & \rho_{s}=\frac{\rho}{2}=\frac{1000}{2}=500 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} m \ddot{x}+f_{\text {Bextra }}^{\prime} &=0 \\ m \ddot{x}+V_{\text {extra }} \cdot \rho \cdot g &=0 \\ \rho \cdot \frac{V_{s}}{2} \ddot{x}+\left(\pi R^{2} \cdot x\right) \rho \cdot g &=0 \\ \frac{4 \pi R^{3}}{3} \hat{x}+\pi R^{2} x g &=0 \\ \ddot{x}+\frac{3 g}{2 R} x &=0 \\ \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 R}}=\sqrt{\frac{3 \times 10}{2 \times 0.20}}=\sqrt{\frac{30}{0.4}} \\ \omega_{n}&=\sqrt{\frac{300}{4}}=\sqrt{75}=8.66 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 40 The sun (S) and the planet (P) of an epicyclic gear train shown in the figure have identical
number of teeth If the sun (S) and the outer ring (R) gears are rotated in the same direction with angular
speed [latex]\omega _S \; and \; \omega _R[/latex], respectively, then the angular speed of the arm AB is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} r_{s}+2 r_{p}&=r_{R} \\ \Rightarrow \quad T_{s}+2 T_{p}&=T_{R} \quad (T_{P}=T_{S})\\ 3 T_{P}&=T_{R} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 3 T_{p}&=T_{R} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} y+x&=\omega_{S} \\ y-\frac{x}{3}&=\omega_{R}\\ & \text{Substract by,}\\ \frac{4 x}{3} &=\left(\omega_{S}-\omega_{R}\right) \\ x &=\frac{3}{4}\left(\omega_{S}-\omega_{R}\right) \\ y &=\omega_{S}-x=\omega_{S}-\frac{3}{4}\left(\omega_{S}-\omega_{R}\right) \\ &=\omega_{S}-\frac{3 \omega_{S}}{4}+\frac{3 \omega_{R}}{4}=\frac{\omega_{S}}{4}+\frac{3 \omega_{R}}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 The number of qualitatively distinct kinematic inversions possible for a Grashof chain with four revolute pairs is
solution: They are: 1. Double crank mechanism 2. Crank-rocker mechanism 3. Double rocker mechanism

question: Question 42 The equation of motion of a spring-mass-damper system is given by [latex]\frac{d^2x}{dt^2}+3\frac{dx}{dt}+9x=10 \sin (5t)[/latex] The damping factor for the system is
solution: [latex]\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}+3\left(\frac{d x}{d t}\right)+9 x=10 \sin 5 t[/latex] Comparing with standard equation: [latex] \ddot{x}+\left(2 \xi \omega_{n}\right) \dot{x}+\left(\omega_{n}^{2}\right) x=\left(\frac{F_{o}}{m}\right) \sin \omega t[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 \xi \omega_{n} &=3 \\ 2 \xi \times 3 &=3 &\left[\begin{array}{l} \omega_{n}^{2}=9 \\ \omega_{n}=3 \end{array}\right] \\ \xi &=\frac{1}{2}=0.5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 43 A cam with a translating flat-face follower is desired to have the follower motion [latex]y(\theta ) = 4[2 \pi \theta - \theta ^2], 0 \leq \theta \leq 2 \pi[/latex] Contact stress considerations dictate that the radius of curvature of the cam profile should
not be less than 40 mm anywhere. The minimum permissible base circle radius
is _____ mm (round off to one decimal place)
solution: Flat face follower Displacement equation: [latex] \begin{aligned} y&=4\left(2 \pi \theta-\theta^{2}\right)\\ \frac{d y}{d \theta} &=V=4(2 \pi-2 \theta) \\ &=8(\pi-\theta) \\ \quad(\text { For } y \text { to be } \max \frac{d y}{d \theta}&=0 \Rightarrow \theta=\pi) \\ a &=\frac{d v}{d \theta}=-8 \\ \left(R_{\text {curvature }}\right)_{\operatorname{Min}} &=R_{\text {Base }}+(y+a)_{\min } \\ \quad(y_{min} & \text{ is 0 at 0},2\pi)\\ 40 &=R_{\text {Base }}+[0-8]_{\operatorname{Min}} \\ 40 &=R_{\text {Base }}+[-8] \\ R_{\text {Base }} &=40-(-8)=40+8=48 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 45 The 2 kg block shown in figure (top view) rests on a smooth horizontal surface and is
attached to a massless elastic cord that has a stiffness 5 N/m. The cord hinged at [latex]O[/latex] is initially unstretched and always remains elastic. The block is
given a velocity [latex]v[/latex] of 1.5 m/s perpendicular to the cord. The magnitude of velocity in
m/s of the block at the instant the cord is stretched by 0.4 m is
solution: Energy conservation [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} m V_{1}^{2} &=\frac{1}{2} m V_{0}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k x^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 2 \times 1.5^{2} &=2 \times V_{0}^{2}+5 \times 0.4^{2} \\ V_{0} &=1.360 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 46 A balanced rigid disc mounted on a rigid rotor has four identical point masses, each
of 10 grams, attached to four points on the 100 mm radius circle shown in the figure. The rotor is driven by a motor at uniform angular speed of 10 rad/s. If one of the masses
gets detached then the magnitude of the resultant unbalance force on the rotor is ______
N. (round off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\omega=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}, r=100 \mathrm{mm}=0.1 \mathrm{m} [/latex] If one mass is detached then Now, unbalance tone, F=[latex]m r \omega^{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{10}{1000} \times 0.1 \times(10)^{2}=\frac{10 \times 0.1 \times 100}{1000} \\ =0.1 \mathrm{N} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 47 A flywheel is attached to an engine to keep its rotational speed between 100 rad/s and
110 rad/s. If the energy fluctuation in the flywheel between these two speeds is 1.05 kJ
then the moment of inertia of the flywheel is _________________kg.[latex]m^2[/latex]  (round off to 2
decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta E_{\max } &=\frac{1}{2} I\left(\omega_{\max }^{2}-\omega_{\min }^{2}\right) \\ \therefore \qquad 1.05 \times 10^{3} \times 2 &=I\left(110^{2}-100^{2}\right) \\ I &=1 \mathrm{kg} . \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 48 A four bar mechanism is shown below For the mechanism to be a crank-rocker mechanism, the length of the link PQ can be

For Crank-Rocker mechanism, shortest link must be crank and adjacent to fixed as well 
as Grashoff's law must be satisfied. If [latex]l = 80 mm[/latex]
then shortest will be = 80 mm as well as (80 + 600) [latex]\lt[/latex](400 + 300) 680 [latex]\lt[/latex] 700 Therefore law is satisfied. [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] l = 80 mm

question: Question 49 A single-degree-of-freedom oscillator is subjected to harmonic excitation [latex]F(t) = F_0 \cos (\omega t)[/latex] as shown in the figure. The non-zero value of [latex]\omega[/latex], for which the amplitude of the force transmitted to the ground will be [latex]F_0[/latex], is
solution: Given, [latex]F_{1}=F_{0}[/latex] then transmissibility [latex]\epsilon =\frac{F_{T}}{F_{0}}=\frac{F_{0}}{F_{0}}=1[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\sqrt{1+\left ( \frac{2\xi \omega }{\omega _n} \right )^2}}{\left ( 1-\left ( \frac{\omega }{\omega _n} \right )^2 \right )^2+\left ( \frac{2\xi \omega }{\omega _n} \right )^2}=1 \\ 1+ \left ( \frac{2\xi \omega }{\omega _n} \right )^2=\left ( 1-\left ( \frac{\omega }{\omega _n} \right )^2 \right )^2+ \left ( \frac{2\xi \omega }{\omega _n} \right )^2\\ 1-\left ( \frac{\omega }{\omega _n} \right )^2 =\pm 1 \\ \text{ Taking (-ve) sign,} \\ 1-\left ( \frac{\omega }{\omega _n} \right )^2 =-1 \\ \frac{\omega }{\omega _n} =\sqrt{2}\\ \omega=\sqrt{2}\omega_n=\sqrt{\frac{2k}{m}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 A uniform disc with radius r and a mass of m kg is mounted centrally on a horizontal axle of negligible mass and length of 1.5r. The disc spins counter-clockwise about the axle with angular speed [latex]\omega[/latex], when viewed from the right-hand side bearing, Q. The axle precesses about a vertical axis at [latex]\omega_p=\omega /10[/latex] in the clockwise direction when viewed from above. Let [latex]R_P \; and \; R_Q[/latex] (positive upwards) be the resultant reaction forces due to the mass and the gyroscopic effect, at bearings P and Q, respectively. Assuming [latex]\omega^2 r=300m/s^2[/latex] and [latex]g=10m/s^2[/latex], the ratio of the larger to the smaller bearing reaction force (considering appropriate signs) is_______
solution: Given: [latex] \begin{aligned} &\omega_{\mathrm{p}}=\frac{\omega}{10} \\ &\omega^{2}=300 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ &\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ &\Sigma \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{y}}=0 \Rightarrow \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{p}}+\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{Q}}=\mathrm{mg} \ldots(i)\\ &\Rightarrow \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{Q}}(1.5 \mathrm{r})=(\mathrm{mg} \times 1.5) \frac{\mathrm{r}}{2}+\mathrm{I} \omega . \omega_{\mathrm{p}} \\ &\Rightarrow(1.5 \mathrm{r}) \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{Q}}=\mathrm{mg} \times \frac{1.5 \mathrm{r}}{2}+\frac{\mathrm{mr}^{2}}{2} \frac{\omega^{2}}{10} \\ &\Rightarrow(1.5 \mathrm{R}) \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{Q}}=\mathrm{mg} \times \frac{1.5 \mathrm{r}}{2}+\frac{\mathrm{m}}{2} \frac{\left(\mathrm{r} \omega^{2}\right) \mathrm{r}}{10} \\ &\Rightarrow 1.5 \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{Q}}=\frac{1.5 \mathrm{mg}}{2}+\frac{\mathrm{m}}{2} \times \frac{300}{10} \\ &\Rightarrow R_{Q}=15 \mathrm{m}\ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] From equation (i) and (ii) [latex] \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{P}}+15 \mathrm{m}=10 \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] R_{p}=-5 \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \frac{R_{\text {larger }}}{R_{\text {smaller }}}=\frac{R_{Q}}{R_{p}}=\frac{15 \mathrm{m}}{-5 \mathrm{m}}=-3[/latex]

question: Question 51 A four bar mechanism is shown in the figure. The link numbers are mentioned near the links. Input link 2 is rotating anticlockwise with a constant angular speed [latex]\omega _2[/latex]. Length of different links are: [latex]O_2O_4=O_2A=L,[/latex] [latex]AB=O_4B=\sqrt{2}L.[/latex] The magnitude of the angular speed of the output link 4 is [latex]\omega _4[/latex] at the instant when link 2 makes an angle of [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex] with [latex]O_2O_4[/latex] as shown. The ratio [latex]\frac{\omega _4}{\omega _2}[/latex] is ______(round off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\mathrm{O}_{2} \mathrm{A}=\mathrm{O}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}=\mathrm{L}\\ &\mathrm{AB}=\mathrm{O}_{4} \mathrm{B}=\mathrm{L} \sqrt{2}\\ &\omega_{2} \mathrm{I}_{12} \mathrm{I}_{24}=\omega_{4} \mathrm{I}_{14} \mathrm{I}_{24}\\ &\frac{\omega_{4}}{\omega_{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{I}_{12} \mathrm{I}_{24}}{\mathrm{I}_{14} \mathrm{I}_{24}}\\ &\text { from triangle } \mathrm{O}_{2} \mathrm{AI}_{24}\\ &\frac{I_{12} I_{24}}{\sin 75}=\frac{L}{\sin 15}\\ &\mathrm{I}_{12} \mathrm{I}_{24}=\mathrm{L} \frac{\sin 75}{\sin 15}=3.73 \mathrm{L}\\ &\mathrm{I}_{14} \mathrm{I}_{24}=3.73 \mathrm{L}+\mathrm{L}=4.73 \mathrm{L}\\ &\frac{\omega_{4}}{\omega_{2}}=\frac{\mathrm{I}_{12} \mathrm{I}_{24}}{\mathrm{I}_{14} \mathrm{I}_{24}}=\frac{3.73 \mathrm{L}}{4.73 \mathrm{L}}=0.789 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 Two masses A and B having mass [latex]m_a \; and \; m_b[/latex], respectively, lying in the plane of the figure shown, are rigidly attached to a shaft which revolves about an axis through O perpendicular to the plane of the figure. The radii of rotation of the masses [latex]m_a \; and \; m_b[/latex] are [latex]r_a \; and \; r_b[/latex], respectively. The angle between lines OA and OB is [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]. If [latex]m_a =10 kg, m_b=20kg[/latex], [latex]r_a=200mm, r_b=400mm[/latex], then the balance mass to be placed at a radius of 200 mm is ______ kg (round off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{A}}=10 \mathrm{kg} \\ \mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{B}}=20 \mathrm{kg} \\ \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{A}}=200 \mathrm{mm} \\ \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{B}}=400 \mathrm{mm} \\ \mathrm{r}=200 \mathrm{mm} \\ \mathrm{mr} \omega^{2}=\sqrt{\left(\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{A}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{A}} \omega^{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{B}} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{B}} \omega^{2}\right)^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \mathrm{m} \times 200=\sqrt{(10 \times 200)^{2}+(20 \times 400)^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \mathrm{m}=41.23 \mathrm{kg} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 53 The crank of a slider-crank mechanism rotates counter-clockwise (CCW) with a constant angular velocity [latex]\omega[/latex], as shown. Assume the length of the crank to be r. Using exact analysis, the acceleration of the slider in the y direction, at the instant shown, where the crank is parallel to x-axis, is given by
solution: since the velocity of the point A and B are parallel [latex]\omega_{A B}=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}_{\mathrm{B}}=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}_{\mathrm{A}}+\overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}_{\mathrm{AB}} \\ \overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}_{\mathrm{B}}=\mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{B}} \hat{\mathrm{j}} \\ \overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}_{\mathrm{A}}=-\omega^{2} \mathrm{r} \hat{\mathrm{i}} \\ \overrightarrow{\mathrm{a}}_{\mathrm{AB}}=-\alpha \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{AB}} \sin 45 \hat{\mathrm{i}}-\alpha \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{AB}} \cos 45 \hat{\mathrm{j}} \\ \quad\left(\because \omega^{2} \mathrm{r}_{\mathrm{AB}} \text { along link } \mathrm{AB}=0\right) \\ \mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{B}} \hat{\mathrm{j}}=-\omega^{2} \mathrm{r} \hat{\mathrm{r}}-(\alpha \hat{\mathrm{i}}+\alpha \hat{\mathrm{j}}) \quad=-\left(\omega^{2} \mathrm{r}+\alpha\right) \hat{\mathrm{i}}-\alpha \hat{\mathrm{j}} \\ \omega^{2} \mathrm{r}+\alpha=0 \\ \alpha=-\omega^{2} \mathrm{r} \\ \mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{B}}=-\alpha=-\left(-\omega^{2} \mathrm{r}\right)=\omega^{2} \mathrm{r} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A slender uniform rigid bar of mass m is hinged at O and supported by two springs, with stiffnesses 3k and k,and a damper with damping coefficient c, as shown in the figure. For the system to be critically damped, the ratio [latex]c/\sqrt{km}[/latex] should be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x_{s_{t}}&=\frac{L}{4} \sin \theta \approx \frac{L}{4} \theta \\ x_{s_{2}}&=\frac{3 L}{4} \sin \theta \approx \frac{3 L}{4} \theta \\ x_{d}&=\frac{L}{4} \sin \theta \approx \frac{L}{4} \theta \\ \dot{\mathrm{x}}_{\mathrm{d}}&=\frac{\mathrm{L}}{4} \dot{\theta} \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking moment about 'P' [latex] \begin{aligned} &\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}} \ddot{\theta}+\mathrm{c} \dot{\mathrm{x}}_{\mathrm{d}} \frac{\mathrm{L}}{4}+\mathrm{kx}_{\mathrm{s}_{2}} \cdot \frac{3 \mathrm{L}}{4}+3 \mathrm{kx}_{\mathrm{s}_{1}} \frac{\mathrm{L}}{4}=0 \\ &\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}} \ddot{\theta}+\mathrm{C}\left(\frac{\mathrm{L}}{4}\right)^{2} \dot{\theta}+\mathrm{k}\left(\frac{3 \mathrm{L}}{4}\right)^{2} \theta+3 \mathrm{k}\left(\frac{\mathrm{L}}{4}\right)^{2} \theta=0 \\ &\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}} \ddot{\theta}+\frac{\mathrm{CL}^{2}}{16} \dot{\theta}+\left(\frac{9 \mathrm{L}^{2} \mathrm{k}}{16}+\frac{3 \mathrm{kL}^{2}}{16}\right) \theta=0 \\ &\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}} \ddot{\theta}+\frac{\mathrm{CL}^{2}}{16} \dot{\theta}+\frac{3}{4} \mathrm{kL}^{2} \theta=0 \\ &\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{eq}}=\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}}=\frac{\mathrm{m} \ell^{2}}{12}+\frac{\mathrm{m} \ell^{2}}{16}=\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}}=\frac{7}{48} \mathrm{ml}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{array}{l} \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{\mathrm{C} \ell^{2}}{16} \\ \mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{3 \mathrm{k} \ell^{2}}{4} \\ \omega_{\mathrm{n}}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{eq}}}{\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}}}}=\sqrt{\frac{3 \mathrm{k} \ell^{2}}{4 \times \frac{7 \mathrm{m} \ell^{2}}{48}}}=\sqrt{\frac{36 \mathrm{k}}{7 \mathrm{m}}} \\ \omega_{\mathrm{n}=}=6 \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{k}}{7 \mathrm{m}}} \\ \zeta=\frac{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{eq}}}{2 \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{cq}} \omega_{\mathrm{n}}}=\frac{\mathrm{C} \ell^{2}}{2 \times 16 \times \frac{7 \ell^{2}}{48} \times 6 \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{k}}{7 \mathrm{m}}}} \\ 2 \times 16 \times \frac{7 \times 6^{2}}{48 \sqrt{7}}=\frac{\mathrm{C}}{\sqrt{\mathrm{k} \cdot \mathrm{m}}} \\ \frac{\mathrm{C}}{\sqrt{\mathrm{km}}}=2 \times 2 \sqrt{7}=4 \sqrt{7} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 55 A spur gear has pitch circle diameter D and number of teeth T. The circular pitch of the gear is
solution: Circular pitch : It is the distance between two similar points on adjacent teeth measured along pitch circle circumference circular pitch [latex] \left(P_{c}\right)=\frac{\text { Pitch circlecircum }}{\text { Number of teeth }}=\frac{\pi D}{T}[/latex]

question: Question 56 A rigid triangular body, PQR, with sides of equal length of 1 unit moves on a flat plane. At the instant shown, edge QR is parallel to the x-axis, and the body moves such that velocities of points P and R are [latex]V_P \; and \; V_R[/latex], in the x and y directions, respectively. The magnitude of the angular velocity of the body is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{R}}=(\mathrm{IR}) \omega \\ \Rightarrow \omega=\frac{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{R}}}{(\mathrm{IR})} \\ \Rightarrow \omega \times \frac{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{R}}}{\frac{1}{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \omega=2 \mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{R}} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 57 A uniform thin disk of mass 1kg and radius 0.1m is kept on a surface asshown in the figure. A spring of stiffness [latex]k_1=400N/m[/latex] is connected to the diskcenter A and another spring of stiffness [latex]k_2=100N/m[/latex] is connected at point B just above point A on the circumference of the disk. Initially, both thesprings are unstretched. Assume pure rolling of the disk. For small disturbance from the equilibrium, the natural frequency of vibration of the system is______rad/s(round off to onedecimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}} \ddot{\theta}+\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{s}_{1}} \cdot \mathrm{r} \cos \theta+\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{s}_{2}}(2 \mathrm{r} \cos \theta)=0 \\ \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}} \ddot{\theta}+\mathrm{k}_{1} \cdot \mathrm{x}_{\mathrm{s}_{1}} \cdot \mathrm{r}+\mathrm{k}_{2} \mathrm{x}_{\mathrm{s}_{2}} \cdot 2 \mathrm{r}=0 \\ \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}} \ddot{\theta}+\mathrm{k}_{1} \cdot \mathrm{r}^{2} \theta+\mathrm{k}_{2} 4 \mathrm{r}^{2} \theta=0 \\ \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}} \ddot{\theta}+\left(\mathrm{k}_{1} \mathrm{r}^{2}+4 \mathrm{k}_{2} \mathrm{r}^{2}\right) \mid=0 \\ \begin{array}{l} \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{eq}}=\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{p}}=\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{cm}}+\mathrm{m}(\mathrm{r})^{2} \\ =\frac{\mathrm{mr}^{2}}{2}+\mathrm{mr}^{2}=\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{mr}^{2} \end{array} \\ \omega_{\mathrm{n}}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{k}_{1} \mathrm{r}^{2}+4 \mathrm{k}_{2} \mathrm{r}^{2}}{\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{mr}^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{400+(4 \times 100)}{\frac{3}{2} \times 1}}=23.09 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 58 The rotor of a turbojet engine of an aircraft has a mass 180 kg and polar moment of inertia 10 [latex]kg\cdot m^2[/latex] about the rotor axis. The rotor rotates at a constant speed of 1100 rad/s in the clockwise direction when viewed from the front of the aircraft. The aircraft while flying at a speed of 800 km per hour takes a turn with a radius of 1.5 km to the left. The gyroscopic moment exerted by the rotor on the aircraft structure and the direction of motion of the nose when the aircraft turns, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{mass of rotor }&=180 \mathrm{kg} \\ \mathrm{I}&=10 \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \omega_{\mathrm{s}}&=1100 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \mathrm{v}&=800 \mathrm{kmph} \\ \mathrm{R}&=1.5 \mathrm{km} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \mathrm{I}=\mathrm{I} \omega_{\mathrm{S}} \omega_{\mathrm{p}}=1629.62 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} [/latex] Nose goes down

options.A: 1629.6 N-m and the nose goes up
options.B: 1629.6 N-m and the nose goes down
options.C: 162.9 N-m and the nose goes up
options.D: 162.9 N-m and the nose goes down

question: Question 59 In a four bar planar mechanism shown in the figure, AB = 5 cm, AD = 4 cm and DC = 2 cm. In the configuration shown, both AB and DC are perpendicular to AD. The bar AB rotates with an angular velocity of 10 rad/s. The magnitude of angular velocity (in rad/s) of bar DC at this instant is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \mathrm{AB}=5 \mathrm{cm} \\ \mathrm{AD}=4 \mathrm{cm} \\ \mathrm{DC}=2 \mathrm{cm} \\ \omega_{\mathrm{AB}}=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \because A \mathrm{B} \| \mathrm{DC} \\ \therefore A B \cdot \omega_{\mathrm{AB}}=\mathrm{DC} \cdot \omega_{\mathrm{DC}} \\ 5 \times 10=2 \times \omega_{\mathrm{DC}} \\ \omega_{\mathrm{DC}}=25 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 60 A spur gear with 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] full depth teeth is transmitting 20 kW at 200 rad/s. The pitch circle diameter of the gear is 100 mm. The magnitude of the force applied on the gear in the radial direction is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \phi=20^{\circ}, P=20 k W, \omega=200 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}, d=100 \mathrm{mm}=0.1 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Torque }=\text { Power } / \omega \\ \mathrm{T}=\frac{20000}{200}=100 \mathrm{Nm} \\ \text { Now, } \mathrm{T}=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{T}} \times \frac{\mathrm{d}}{2} \\ \Rightarrow 100=\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{T}} \times \frac{0.1}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{T}}=2000 \mathrm{N}\\ \frac{F_{R}}{F_{T}}=\tan \phi \\ \Rightarrow \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{R}}=2000 \times \tan 20^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{R}}=727.94 \mathrm{N}=0.73 \mathrm{kN} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 61 The natural frequencies corresponding to the spring-mass systems I and II are [latex]\omega _I \; and \; \omega _{II}[/latex], respectively. The ratio [latex]\frac{\omega _I}{\omega _{II}}[/latex] is
solution: System: I [latex] k_{e q}=\frac{k \cdot k}{k+k}=\frac{k}{2} [/latex] [latex] \omega_{\mathrm{n}_{1}}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{k}}{2 \mathrm{m}}} [/latex] System - II [latex] \mathrm{k}_{\mathrm{eq}}=2 \mathrm{k} \quad \omega_{\mathrm{n}_{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \mathrm{k}}{\mathrm{m}}} [/latex] [latex] \frac{\omega_{\mathrm{n}_{1}}}{\omega_{\mathrm{n}_{2}}}=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{k}}{2 \mathrm{m}}}}{\sqrt{\frac{2 \mathrm{k}}{\mathrm{m}}}}=\sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{k}}{2 \mathrm{m}} \times \frac{\mathrm{m}}{2 \mathrm{k}}}=\frac{1}{2}[/latex]

question: Question 62 A flat-faced follower is driven using a circular eccentric cam rotating at a constant angular velocity [latex]\omega[/latex]. At time t=0, the vertical position of the followeris y(0)=0, and the system is in the configuration shown below. The vertical position of the follower face, y(t) is given by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{AA}_{1}=\mathrm{y} &=\mathrm{e}(1-\cos \theta) \\ &=\mathrm{e}(1-\cos \omega \mathrm{t}) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 63 A thin-walled cylindrical can with rigid end caps has a mean radius R=100 mm and a wall thickness of  t=5 mm . The can is pressurized and an additional tensile stress of 50 MPa is imposed along the axial direction as shown in the figure. Assume that the state of stress in the wall is uniform along its length. If the magnitudes of axial and circumferential components of stress in the can are equal, the pressure (in MPa) inside the can is ___________ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: Circumferential stress, [latex]\sigma_{n}=\frac{P R}{t} [/latex] [latex] \text { Axial stress, } \sigma_{L}=\frac{P R}{2 t}+50 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} {Now,}\quad \sigma_{n} &=\sigma_{L} \\ \frac{P R}{t} &=\frac{P R}{2 t}+50 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \therefore\quad \frac{P R}{2 t} &=50 \mathrm{MPa}\\ P&=\frac{50 \times 2 \times 5}{100}=5 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 64 In a cam-follower,the follower rises by h as the cam rotates by [latex]\delta [/latex] (radians)  at constant angular velocity [latex]\omega [/latex] ( radins/ s ). The follower is uniformly accelerating during the first half of the rise period and it is uniformly decelerating in the latter half of the rise period. Assuming that the magnitudes of the acceleration and deceleration are same, the maximum velocity of the follower is
solution: Here, outstroke angle [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta_{0} &=\delta \\ \text { and stroke length } &=h \\ \text { angular velocity } &=\omega \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} V &=u+a t \\ \left(V_{0}\right)_{\max } &=0+a \times \frac{t_{0}}{2}=a \times \frac{\delta}{2 \omega} \quad \ldots(i)\\ \frac{h}{2} &=0+\frac{1}{2} a\left(\frac{t_{0}}{2}\right)^{2} \\ h &=\frac{a t_{0}^{2}}{4}=\frac{a \delta^{2}}{4 \omega_{2}} \\ a &=\frac{4 \omega^{2} \cdot h}{\delta^{2}} \quad\ldots(ii)\\ &\text{ By(i) and (ii),} \\ \left(V_{0}\right)_{\max } &=\frac{a \delta}{2 \omega}=\frac{4 \omega^{2} \cdot h}{\delta^{2}} \times \frac{\delta}{2 \omega}=\frac{2 \omega \cdot h}{\delta} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 In a single degree of freedom underdamped spring-mass-damper system as shown in the figure, an additional damper is added in parallel such that the system still remains underdamped. Which one of the following statements is ALWAYS true?
solution: [latex]\text { Tansmissibility, } \quad \in=\frac{\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{2 \xi \omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}}}{\sqrt{\left\{1-\left(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}\right\}^{2}+\left\{\frac{2 \xi \omega}{\omega_{n}}\right\}^{2}}}[/latex] Additional damper is added into parallel. Then damping will increase. But it is still under damped. But [latex]\xi[/latex] will increase. Here no unbalance force is there. But  [latex]\omega_{d}=\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}} \cdot \omega_{n} \quad\left\{\omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{M}}\right\}[/latex] But as [latex]\xi[/latex] increases then [latex]\xi^{2}[/latex] will increase Then [latex]\omega_{d}[/latex] will decrease Then [latex]T_{d}=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega_{d}} \text { will increase }[/latex]

options.C: Time period of free oscillations will increase.
options.D: Time period of free oscillations will decrease.

question: Question 66 A frictionless gear train is shown in the figure. The leftmost 12-teeth gear is given a torque of 100 N-m. The output torque from the 60-teeth gear on the right in N-m is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau_{1}&=100 \mathrm{Nm}\\ \text{Let speed of 1 is }N_{1} \\ (1,2):\qquad N_{2}&=N_{1} \times \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}=N_{1} \times \frac{12}{48}=\frac{N_{1}}{4} \\ N_{3}=N_{2}&=\frac{N_{1}}{4}\\ (3,4) \qquad N_{4}&=N_{3} \times \frac{T_{3}}{T_{4}}=\frac{N_{1}}{4} \times \frac{12}{60} \\ N_{4}&=\frac{N_{1}}{20} \end{aligned}[/latex] By Power conservation (Assume [latex]\eta[/latex] (efficiency) =1) [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau_{1} \times N_{1} &=\tau_{4} \times N_{4} \\ 100 \times N_{1} &=\tau_{4} \times \frac{N_{1}}{20} \\ \tau_{4} &=2000 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 67 A slider crank mechanism is shown in the figure. At some instant, the crank angle is [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex] and a force of 40 N is acting towards the left on the slider. The length of the crank is 30 mm and the connecting rod is 70 mm. Ignoring the effect of gravity, friction and inertial forces, the magnitude of the crankshaft torque (in Nm) needed to keep the mechanism in equilibrium is _________ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} 30 \sin 45^{\circ} &=70 \sin \beta \\ \sin \beta &=\frac{30 \sin 45}{70}=0.303045 \\ \beta &=17.6406^{\circ} \\ F_{C} \cos \beta &=40 \\ F_{C} &=\frac{40}{\cos \beta}=41.9737 \mathrm{N} \\ F_{t} &=F_{C} \sin (\theta+\beta) \\ &=41.9737 \times \sin \left(17.6406^{\circ}+45^{\circ}\right) \\ F_{t} &=37.2785 \mathrm{N} \\ T &=F_{t} \times r=47.2785 \times 0.030 \\ &=1.1183 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m}=1.118 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} \\ &=1.12 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 A machine of mass m = 200 kg is supported on two mounts, each of stiffness k = 10 kN/m. The machine is subjected to an external force (in N) F(t)=50cos5t. Assuming only vertical translatory motion, the magnitude of the dynamic force (in N) transmitted from each mount to the ground is ______ (correct to two decimal places).
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned} m&=200 \mathrm{kg}, k=10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}=10000 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \\ \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{eq}}&=K+K=10000+10000=20000 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \\ F_{t}&=50 \cos 5 t \\ F_{0}&=50 \mathrm{N} \\ \omega&=5 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \omega_{n}&=\sqrt{\frac{K_{e q}}{m}}=\sqrt{\frac{20000}{200}} \\ &=\sqrt{100}=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}&=\frac{5}{10}=\frac{1}{2} \\ \mathrm{Nodamping\Rightarrow} c=0 &\Rightarrow \xi=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] No damping [latex]\Rightarrow c=0 \Rightarrow \xi=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Transmissibility}\quad \epsilon&=\frac{\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{2 \xi \omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}}}{\sqrt{\left\{1-\left(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}\right\}^{2}+\left\{\frac{2 \xi \omega}{\omega_{n}}\right\}^{2}}} \qquad (\xi=0)\\ &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left\{1-\left(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}\right\}^{2}}} \\ &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left\{1-\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}\right\}^{2}}}\\ &=\frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{4}}=\frac{1}{\frac{3}{4}}=\left(\frac{4}{3}\right) \\ \epsilon&=\frac{F_{t}}{F_{0}} \frac{3}{4}&=\frac{F_t}{50} \\
F_t&=\frac{200}{3}=66.666N\\
&\text{Force from each mount}\\
&=\frac{F_t}{2}=\frac{66.666}{2}=33.333N\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 69 An epicyclic gear train is shown in the figure below. The number of teeth on the gears A, B and D are 20, 30 and 20, respectively. Gear C has 80 teeth on the inner surface and 100 teeth on the outer surface. If the carrier arm AB is fixed and the sun gear A rotates at 300 rpm in the clockwise direction, then the rpm of D in the clockwise direction is
solution: [latex]T_{A}=20, T_{B}=30, T_{D}=20, T_{C}=80(\text { Inner }), T_{C}=100 \text { (Outer) }[/latex] Arm is fixed, no epicyclic nature. Taking clockwise direction as positive. [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{A}&=+300 \\ (A, B) \qquad N_{B}&=-\frac{300 \times 20}{30}=-200\\ (B, C)\qquad N_{C}&=-200 \times \frac{30}{80}=-75\\ (C, D)\qquad N_{D}&=+75 \times \frac{100}{20}=+375 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 70 A four  bar mechanism  is made  up of  links of length  100, 200, 300 and 350 mm. If  the 350 mm link is fixed, the number of links that can rotate fully is __________.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} s=100, p=200, l=350, q=300 \\ (s+l)=350+100=450 \lt (p+q) \\ 450 \lt 200+300 \\ 450 \lt 500 \end{array}[/latex] Grashot law is satisfied. 350 mm link is fixed. Then, shortest link = 100mm s adjacent to fixed, will give crank only.

question: Question 71 The equation of motion for a spring-mass system excited by a harmonic force is [latex]M\ddot{x} + Kx = Fcos(\omega t)[/latex] where M is the mass, K is the spring stiffness, F is the force amplitude and is the angular frequency of excitation. Resonance occurs when is equal to
solution: [latex]M \ddot{x}+K x=f \cos (\omega t)[/latex] Resonance is when [latex]  \quad \omega=\omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{M}}[/latex]

question: Question 72 Three masses are connected to a rotating shaft supported on bearings A and B as shown in the figure. The system is in a space where the gravitational effect is absent. Neglect the mass of shaft and rods connecting the masses.for [latex]m_{1}=10[/latex] kg,[latex]m_{2}=5[/latex] kg and [latex]m_{3}=2.5[/latex] kg and for a shaft angular speed of 1000 radian/s, the magnitude of the bearing reaction (in N) at location B is_____
solution: It means all three masses are in same plane let us calculates the net force [latex] \begin{array}{c} \Sigma F_{x}= \Sigma \mathrm{m} \mathrm{r} \omega^{2} \cos \theta \\ =\left(10 \times 0.1 \times \omega^{2}\right)-\left(5 \times 0.2 \times 6^{2} \cos 60^{\circ}\right) \\ -\left(2.5 \times 0.4 \times \omega^{2} \cos 60^{\circ}\right) \\ =\left[1-\left(5 \times 0.2 \times \frac{1}{2}\right)-\left(2.5 \times 0.4 \times \frac{1}{2}\right)\right] \omega^{2}=0 \\ \Sigma F_{y}= \Sigma \mathrm{mr} \omega^{2} \sin \theta \\ =\left(5 \times 0.2 \times \omega^{2} \sin 60^{\circ}\right) \\ -\left(2.5 \times 0.4 \times \omega^{2} \sin 60^{\circ}\right) \\ =\left[\left(1 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)-\left(1 \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)\right] \omega^{2} \\ =\left[\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)\right] \omega^{2}=0 \end{array}[/latex] Net force, [latex] =\sqrt{\Sigma F_{x}^{2}+\Sigma F_{y}^{2}}=0[/latex] Therefore reaction at B is zero. [latex] R_{B}=0[/latex]

question: Question 73 A gear train shown in the figure consists of gear P, Q, R and S. Gear Q and gear R are mounted on the same shaft. All the gears are mounted on parallel shafts and the number of teeth of P, Q, R and S are 24, 45, 30 and 80, respectively. Gear P is rotating at 400 rpm. The speed (in rpm) of the gear S is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{ll} T_{P}=24 \\ T_{Q}=45 & N_{P}=400 \mathrm{rpm} \\ T_{R}=30 & N_{S}=? \\ T_{S}=80 \end{array}[/latex] [latex] Here gear R is not meshing at all. [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{N_{P}}{N_{Q}}=\frac{T_{O}}{T_{P}}=\frac{45}{24} \qquad \cdots(1)\\ \frac{N_{Q}}{N_{S}}=\frac{T_{S}}{T_{Q}}=\frac{80}{45}\qquad \cdots(2)\\ \text{By }(1) \times(2) \\ \frac{N_{P}}{N_{S}}=\frac{45}{24} \times \frac{80}{45} \\ N_{S}=N_{P} \times \frac{24}{80}=\frac{400 \times 24}{80} \\ N_{S}=120 \text { r.p.m } \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 74 The radius of gyration of a compound pendulum about the point of suspension is 100mm. The distance between the point of suspension and the centre of mass is 250mm. Considering the acceleration due to gravity as [latex](9.81\, m/s^{2})[/latex], the natural frequency (in radian/s) of the compound pendulum is ______.
solution: If we displace this by an angle [latex]\theta[/latex] clockwise: [latex]I \ddot{\theta}+m g \cdot a \sin \theta=0[/latex] Taking [latex]\theta [/latex] very small: [latex] \begin{array}{c} \sin \theta \approx \theta \qquad(k=100 \mathrm{mm}=0.1 \mathrm{m}) \\ \mathrm{r} \ddot{\theta}+\mathrm{mg} \cdot \mathrm{a} \cdot \theta=0 \\ \ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{\mathrm{mg}}{\mathrm{I}} \mathrm{a}\right) \theta=0 \\ \mathrm{Here} \quad I=m \mathrm{k}^{2}=\mathrm{m}(0.1)^{2} \end{array}[/latex] (I is the MI about the point of Hinge) [latex] \begin{array}{l}\qquad\begin{aligned} I&=m(0.01) \mathrm{kg}-\mathrm{m}^{2} \\ a&=250 \mathrm{mm}=0.250 \mathrm{m} \\ g&=9.81 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}\\ \ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{m \times 9.81 \times 0.250}{(0.01) m}\right) \theta=0 \\ \ddot{\theta}+(245.25) \theta=0 \\ \qquad \omega_{n}=\sqrt{245.25}=15.660 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 75 Block 2 slides outward on link 1 at a uniform velocity of 6 m/s as shown in the figure. Link 1 is rotating at a constant angular velocity of 20 radians/s counterclockwise. The magnitude of the total acceleration [latex](in\, m/s^{2})[/latex] of point P of the block with respect to fixed point O is ___.
solution: [latex] \begin{array}{l} V=6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \omega=20 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex] Here the centripital and corialis acceleration will be there Total Acceleration: [latex] \begin{aligned} a_{p} &=\sqrt{(40)^{2}+(240)^{2}} \\ &=243.310 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 76 In a slider-crank mechanism, the lengths of the crank and the connecting rod are 100mm and 160mm, respectively. The crank is rotating with an angular of 10 radian/s counter-clockwise. The magnitude of linear velocity (in m/s) of the piston at the instant corresponding to the configuration shown in the figure is_____.
solution: After plotting I-centres Here, [latex]I_{23}[/latex] and [latex]I_{24}[/latex] will come at same point Applying angular Velocity Theorem at [latex]I_{24} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \omega_{2}\left(I_{24} I_{12}\right) &=V_{4}=V_{B} \\ V_{B} &=\omega_{2}\left(I_{24} I_{12}\right)=10 \times 0.1 \\ \left(I_{24} I_{12}=100 \mathrm{mm}\right.&=0.1 \mathrm{m}=A B) \\ V_{B} &=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 77 A mass m is attached to two identical springs having spring constant k as shown in the figure. The natural frequency [latex]\omega[/latex]
 of this single degree of freedom system is
solution: Equivalent stiffness [latex] k_{e q}=k+k=2 k[/latex] Natural frequency is [latex] \omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{k_{\mathrm{eq}}}{m}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \mathrm{k}}{\mathrm{m}}}[/latex]

question: Question 78 For an inline slider-crank mechanism, the lengths of the crank and connecting rod are 3m and 4m, respectively. At the instant when the connecting rod is perpendicular to the crank, if the velocity of the slider is 1m/s, the magnitude of angular velocity (upto 3 decimal points accuracy) of the crank is _________ radian/s.
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Here } & V_{B}=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ & \omega_{\text {crank }}=? \end{aligned}[/latex] Let us draw the I-centres Applying angular velocity theorem at [latex]I_{24} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \therefore \omega_{2}\left(I_{24} I_{12}\right)=V_{4}=V_{B}=1 \\ \omega_{2}\left(I_{24} I_{12}\right)=1 \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta &=\tan ^{-1}(4 / 3)=53.13010 \\ \alpha &=90^{\circ}-\theta=36.869 \\ \cos \alpha &=\frac{3}{I_{12} I_{24}} \\ I_{12} I_{24} &=\frac{3}{\cos 36.869}=3.7499 \mathrm{meter} \\ \text{Now}, & \omega_{2}(3.7499)=1 \\ \omega_{2} &=\frac{1}{3.7499}=0.266 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 79 A thin uniform rigid bar of length L and mass M is hinged at point O, located at a distance of  [latex]\frac{L}{3}[/latex]  from one of its ends. The bar is further supported using springs, each of stiffness k, located at the two ends. A particle of mass [latex]m=\frac{M}{4}[/latex]  is fixed at one end of the bar, as shown in the figure. For small rotations of the bar about O, the natural frequency of the systems is
solution: Taking Mass moment of inertia about point 0, [latex] \begin{aligned} I &=\frac{M l^{2}}{12}+M\left(\frac{l}{2}-\frac{l}{3}\right)^{2}+m \times\left(\frac{2 l}{3}\right)^{2} \\ &=\frac{M l^{2}}{12}+\frac{M l^{2}}{36}+\frac{4 M l^{2}}{9} \\ &=\frac{M l^{2}}{9}+\frac{4 M l^{2}}{4 \times 9}=\frac{2 M l^{2}}{9} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now we will balance torque about 0 [latex] \begin{aligned} I \alpha &=k \times \frac{2 L}{3} \times\left(\frac{2 L}{3} \theta\right)+k \times \frac{L}{3} \times\left(\frac{L}{3} \theta\right) \\ \frac{2 M l^{2}}{9} \frac{d^{2} \theta}{d t^{2}} &=\frac{5 k}{2 M}=\omega_{n}^{2} \theta \\ \therefore \quad \omega_{n}&=\sqrt{\frac{5 k}{2 M}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 80 In an epicyclic gear train, shown in the figure, the outer ring gear is fixed, while the sun gear rotates counterclockwise at 100rpm. Let the number of teeth on the sun, planet and outer gears to be 50, 25, and 100, respectively. The ratio of magnitudes of angular velocity of the planet gear to the angular velocity of the carrier arm is _________.
solution: We take convention clockwise (+ve) [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{D} &=0 \\ N_{S} &=-100 \\ T_{S} &=50, \quad T_{P}=25, T_{D}=100 \\ \frac{N_{P}}{N_{\mathrm{ARM}}}&=? \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] y+x=-100 \qquad \cdots(i)[/latex] [latex] y-\frac{x}{2}=0 \qquad \cdots(ii)[/latex] By equation (i) - (ii) [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{3 x}{2} &=-100=x=\frac{-200}{3} \\ y &=-100-x=-100+\frac{200}{3}=\frac{-100}{3} \\ N_{p} &=y-2 x=\frac{-100}{3}+\frac{400}{3}=\frac{300}{3}=100 \\ N_{\mathrm{ARM}} &=y=\frac{-100}{3} \\ \frac{N_{P}}{N_{\mathrm{ARM}}} &=\frac{100}{\frac{-100}{3}}=-3 \\ \left| \frac{N_{\mathrm{P}}}{N_{\mathrm{ARM}}}\right | &=3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 81 The damping ratio for a viscously damped spring mss system, governed by the relationship [latex]m\frac{\mathrm{d^{2}}x}{\mathrm{d}  t^{2}}+c\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}+kx=F(t)[/latex], is given by
solution: We know that: [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 \xi \omega_{n} &=\frac{c}{m} \\ \xi &=\frac{c}{m \times 2 \omega_{n}}=\frac{c}{2 m \cdot \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}}=\frac{c}{2 \sqrt{k m}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 82 A single degree of freedom spring-mass system is subjected to a harmonic force of constant amplitude. For an excitation frequency of [latex]\sqrt{3k/m}[/latex] the ratio of the amplitude of steady state response to the static deflection of the spring is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{A}{x_{0}} &=\text { Magnification factor } \\ \frac{A}{F_{0} / k} &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{\omega}{w_{n}}\right)^{2}+\left(2 \zeta \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}}} \\ \because \qquad \zeta &=0 \\ \frac{A}{F_{0} / k} &=\frac{1}{\left(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}-1} \\ \omega &=\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}}, \quad \omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}} \\ \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}} &=\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}} \times \sqrt{\frac{m}{k}} \\ &=\sqrt{3} \\ \frac{A}{F_{0} / k} &=\frac{1}{(\sqrt{3})^{2}-1}=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 83 Two masses m are attached to opposite sides of a rigid rotating shaft in the vertical plane. Another pair of equal masses m1 is attached to the opposite sides of the shaft in the vertical plane as shown in figure. Consider m = 1 kg, e = 50 mm, e1 = 20 mm, b = 0.3 m, a = 2 m and a1 = 2.5 m. For the system to be dynamically balanced, m1 should be ________ kg.
solution: Balance moment of all forces [latex] \begin{array}{c} \omega^{2}\left(m_{1} \times 0.02 \times 2.5\right)+(1 \times 0.05 \times 0.3) \omega^{2}=\left(m_{1} \times\right. \\ 0.02 \times 0) \omega^{2}+(1 \times 0.05 \times 2.3) \omega^{2} \\ m_{1}=2 \mathrm{kg} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 84 The static deflection of a spring under gravity, when a mass of 1 kg is suspended from it, is 1 mm. Assume the acceleration due to gravity g =10 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex]. The natural frequency of this spring-mass system (in rad/s) is_____________
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} g=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ m=1 \mathrm{kg}\\ \text{Deflection:}\; \Delta=1 \mathrm{mm} \\ \omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{\Delta}}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{1 \times 10^{-3}}}=100 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 85 The number of degrees of freedom in a planar mechanism having n links and j simple hinge joints is
solution: Degrees of freedom is given by 3(n-1) - 2j

question: Question 86 The system shown in the figure consists of block A of mass 5 kg connected to a spring through a massless rope passing over pulley B of radius r and mass 20 kg. The spring constant k is 1500 N/m. If there is no slipping of the rope over the pulley, the natural frequency of the system is_____________ rad/s.
solution: Total energy of system [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2} \\ &=\frac{1}{2} m\left(r \times \frac{d \theta}{d t}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K \times(r \theta)^{2} \\&+\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{M r^{2}}{2} \times\left[\frac{d \theta}{d T}\right]^{2} \\ &=\frac{1}{2} M r^{2} \cdot(\dot{\theta})^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K \times r^{2} \theta^{2}+\frac{M r^{2}}{4}(\dot{\theta})^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] since total energy remains constant with respect to time. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d E}{d t} &=0 \\ \frac{d E}{d t} &=\frac{1}{2} m r^{2} 2 \cdot \dot{\theta} \ddot{\theta}+\frac{K r^{2}}{2} \cdot 2 \theta \cdot \dot{\theta}+\frac{M r^{2}}{4} 2 \dot{\theta} \dot{\theta} \\ 0 &=m r^{2} \dot{\theta} \ddot{\theta}+K r^{2} \theta \cdot \dot{\theta}+\frac{M r^{2}}{2} \dot{\theta} \ddot{\theta} \end{aligned}[/latex] Divide both sides by [latex]\dot{\theta} [/latex] [latex] 0=m r^{2} \ddot{\theta}+K r^{2} \theta+\frac{M r^{2}}{2}[/latex] Divide both sides by [latex]r^{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 0 &=m \ddot{\theta}+K \theta+\frac{M \ddot{\theta}}{2} \\ 0 &=\left(m+\frac{M}{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+K \theta \\ 0 &=\ddot{\theta}+\left[\frac{K}{m+\frac{M}{2}}\right] \theta \\ \omega_{n}^{2} &=\frac{K}{m+\frac{M}{2}} \\ \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{2 k}{M+2 m}}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 1500}{20+(2 \times 5)}} \\ &=\sqrt{\frac{3000}{20+10}}=\sqrt{100} \\ &=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 87 The rod AB, of length 1 m, shown in the figure is connected to two sliders at each end through pins. The sliders can slide along QP and QR. If the velocity VA of the slider at A is 2 m/s, the velocity of the midpoint of the rod at this instant is ___________ m/s.
solution: [latex]\omega _3=\omega _{AB}=\frac{V_A}{I_{13A}}=\frac{V_B}{I_{13B}}=\frac{V_C}{I_{13C}}[/latex] [latex] I_{13A}=[/latex] Distance between [latex]I_{13}[/latex] and point A [latex] I_{13B}=[/latex] Distance between [latex]I_{13}[/latex] and point B [latex] I_{13C}=[/latex] Distance between [latex]I_{13}[/latex] and point C [latex] \frac{V_A}{I_{13A}}=\frac{V_C}{I_{13C}}[/latex] [latex] \frac{2}{I_{13A}}=\frac{V_C}{I_{13C}}[/latex] Applying sine law in triangle [latex]ABI_{13}[/latex] [latex]\frac{1}{\sin 120^{\circ}}=\frac{I_{13A}}{\sin 30^{\circ}} I_{13A}=\frac{\sin 30^{\circ}}{\sin 120^{\circ}} Applying sine law in ACI_{13}=0.5774 \begin{aligned} \frac{I_{13C}}{\sin 30^{\circ}} &= \frac{I_{13A}}{\sin 90^{\circ}}\\ I_{13C}&= \frac{I_{13A}\sin 30^{\circ}}{\sin 90^{\circ}}\\ &=0.5774 \times 0.5=0.2887m \\ V_C&=\frac{V_A I_{13C}}{I_{13a}} \\ &=\frac{2 \times 0.2887}{0.5774}=1 m/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 88 A single degree of freedom mass-spring-viscous damper system with mass m, spring constant k and
viscous damping coefficient q is critically damped. The correct relation among m, k, and q is
solution: Given : 1. single degree of freedom 2. Mass =m 3. Spring constant =k 4. Damping coefficient =q 5. Critically damped Damping factor =1 Correct relation: Damping factor = [latex] \begin{array}{c}\ \frac{\text { Damping coefficient }}{2 \times \text { mass } \times \text { Natural frequency of vibration }} \\ 1=\frac{q}{2 \times m \times \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}} \\ q=2 \sqrt{km} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 89 A solid disc with radius a is connected to a spring at a point d above the center of the disc. The other end of the spring is fixed to the vertical wall. The disc is free to roll without slipping on the
ground. The mass of the disc is M and the spring constant is K. The polar moment of inertia for the
disc about its centre is [latex]J=Ma^{2}/2[/latex] The natural frequency of this system in rad/s is given by
solution: Total energy of system [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} M v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K x^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} M \times\left(a \times \frac{d \theta}{d t}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2} K \times \\ \qquad \{(a+d) \theta\}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{M a^{2}}{2} \times\left(\frac{d \theta}{d t}\right)^{2}\\ \text{Let}\qquad \frac{d \theta}{d t}=\dot{\theta} \\ E=\frac{1}{2} M a^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{K}{2}(a+d)^{2} \cdot \theta^{2}+\frac{M a^{2}}{4} \dot{\theta}^{2} \end{array}[/latex] since energy of system remains concerned with respect to time. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d E}{d t}&=0 \\ \frac{d E}{d t}&=\frac{M a^{2}}{2} 2 \cdot \dot{\theta} \cdot \ddot{\theta}+\frac{K}{2}(a+d)^{2} \\ & \qquad \cdot 2 \theta \cdot \dot{\theta}+\frac{M a^{2}}{4} \cdot 2 \dot{\theta} \ddot{\theta} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]0=M a^{2} \dot{\theta} \ddot{\theta}+\frac{\lt a^{2}}{2} \cdot \dot{\theta} \ddot{\theta}+K(a+d)^{2} \theta \cdot \dot{\theta}[/latex] Divide both sides by [latex]\dot{\theta} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} 0&=M a^{2} \ddot{\theta}+\frac{M a^{2}}{2} \cdot \ddot{\theta}+K(a+d)^{2} \cdot \theta \\ 0&=\left(M a^{2}+\frac{M a^{2}}{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+K(a+d)^{2} \theta \\ 0&=\frac{3}{2} M a^{2} \cdot \ddot{\theta}+K(a+d)^{2} \theta \end{aligned}[/latex] Divide both sides by [latex] \frac{3}{2} m a^{2} [/latex] [latex] 0=\ddot{\theta}+\frac{K(a+d)^{2}}{\frac{3 M a^{2}}{2}} \theta[/latex] [latex] \ddot{\theta}+\omega_{n}^{2} \theta=0[/latex] Compairing above two equation [latex] \omega_{n}^{2}=\frac{2 K(a+d)^{2}}{3 M a^{2}} ; \omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{2 K(a+d)^{2}}{3 M a^{2}}}[/latex]

question: Question 90 In the gear train shown, gear 3 is carried on arm 5. Gear 3 meshes with gear 2 and gear 4. The number of teeth on gear 2, 3, and 4 are 60, 20, and 100, respectively. If gear 2 is fixed and gear 4 rotates with an angular velocity of 100 rpm in the counterclockwise direction, the angular speed of arm 5 (in rpm) is
solution: Given : Gear 2 is fixed [latex] \therefore \quad N+y=0 \qquad [\therefore N=-y][/latex] Gear 4 rotates 100 rpm is counter clockwise. [latex] \begin{aligned} -\frac{N \times 60}{100}+y &=-100 \\ +y \times 0.6+y &=-100 \\ y &=\frac{-100}{1.6}=-62.5 \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence angular speed of arm is 62.5 (counterclockwise).

question: Question 91 A slider crank mechanism with crank radius 200 mm and connecting rod length 800 mm is shown. The crank is rotating at 600 rpm in the counterclockwise direction. In the configuration shown, the crank makes an angle of [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]   with the sliding direction of the slider, and a force of 5 kN is acting on the slider. Neglecting the inertia forces, the turning moment on the crank (in kN-m) is __________
solution: Turning moment on crankshaft, [latex] \begin{aligned} T &=F_{T} \times r=\frac{F}{\cos \beta} \times \cos \beta \times r \\ &=F \times r=5 \times 0.2=1 \mathrm{kNm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Alternatively [latex] \begin{aligned} \sin \beta &=\frac{\text { Perpendicular }}{\text { Hypotenuse }} \\ \sin \beta &=\frac{200}{800}=\frac{1}{4}=0.25 \\ \beta &=\sin ^{-1} 0.25=14.478^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Turning moment on crankshaft, [latex] \begin{array}{l} T=F_{t} r=\frac{F}{\cos \beta} \sin (\theta+\beta) \times r \\ =\frac{5}{\cos 14.478} \sin \left[90^{\circ}+14.478^{\circ}\right] \times 0.2 \\ =1 \mathrm{kNm} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 92 A single degree of freedom spring mass system with viscous damping has a spring constant of 10 kN/m. The system is excited by a sinusoidal force of amplitude 100 N. If the damping factor(ratio) is 0.25, the amplitude of steady state oscillation at resonance is ________mm.
solution: Forcing function [latex]=F_{0} \sin \omega t [/latex] Given, [latex]F_{0}=100 \mathrm{N} [/latex] Damping factor, [latex] \xi=0.25[/latex] Spring constant [latex] \begin{aligned} k&=10 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}=10 \times 1000=10000 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \\ A&=\frac{F_{0} / \mathrm{k}}{\sqrt{\left\{1-\left(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}\right\}^{2}+\left(2 \xi \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}}} \end{aligned}[/latex] At resonance [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega &=\omega_{n} \\ \therefore \quad A &=\frac{100}{10000}=\frac{0.01}{2 \xi}=0.02 \mathrm{m} \\ &=20 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 93 A car is moving on a curved horizontal road of radius 100 m with a speed of 20 m/s. The rotating masses of the engine have an angular speed of 100 rad/s in clockwise direction when viewed from the front of the car. The combined moment of inertia of the rotating masses is 10 kg-[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. The magnitude of the gyroscopic moment (in N-m) is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R&=100\;m \\ v&=20\;m/sec \\ \omega _p &=\frac{v}{R} \\ &= 0.2\; rad/sec\\ \omega _s &=100\; rad/sec \\ I&= 10\; Kg-m^2\\ &\text{Gyroscopic moment,}\\ I\omega _s\omega _p &=10 \times 0.2 \times 100\; N-m\\ &=200\; N-m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 94 The torque (in N-m) exerted on the crank shaft of a two stroke engine can be described as [latex]T=10000+1000\sin 2\theta -1200\cos 2\theta,[/latex] where [latex]\theta[/latex] is the crank angle as measured from inner dead center position. Assuming the resisting torque to be constant, the power (in kW) developed by the engine at 100 rpm is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} T=10000+1000 \sin 2 \theta-1200 \cos 2 \theta \\ N=100 \mathrm{rpm} \\ W=\frac{2 \pi \times 100}{60}=10.472 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ T_{\text {man }}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi}[10,000+1000 \sin 2 \theta- \\ =10,000[2 \pi-0]+\frac{1000}{2} \times[\cos 2 \pi]_{0}^{2 \pi} \\ -\frac{1200}{2}[\sin2\theta]_{0}^{2\pi} \\ =\frac{1}{2 \pi}[10,000 \cdot 2 \pi+500 \cdot[\cos 4 \pi-\cos 0] \\ \quad -600[\sin 4 \pi-\sin 0] \\ (10000\times2\pi)+500[1-1]-600[0-0]\\ =\frac{10000 \times 2 \pi}{2 \pi}=10000\\ \text{Power} = 10000\times\frac{2\pi\times100}{60}=104.719\mathrm{kM} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 95 The number of degrees of freedom of the linkage shown in the figure is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F &=3(6-1)-2 \times 7-0 \\ &=15-14=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 96 Figure shows a single degree of freedom system. The system consists of a massless rigid bar OP hinged at O and a mass m at end P. The natural frequency of vibration of the system is
solution: [latex]\therefore[/latex] moving mass m by angle [latex]\theta[/latex] [latex]\therefore [/latex] restoring toque [latex]=k x \times a [/latex] [latex] =k \times(a \theta) \times a [/latex] Restoring torque = inertia torque [latex] \begin{aligned} k\left(a^{2} \theta\right) &=-I \alpha \\ k\left(a^{2} \theta\right) &=-m(2 a)^{2} \ddot{\theta} \\ k \theta &=-m \times 4 a^{2} \ddot{\theta} \\ 4 \ddot{\theta}+k \theta &=0 \\ \ddot{\theta}+\frac{k}{4 m} \theta &=0\\ \therefore \qquad \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{k}{4 m}} \\ \frac{2 \pi}{T} &=\sqrt{\frac{k}{4 m}} \\ T &=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{4 m}{k}}\\ \therefore \qquad f_{n}&=\frac{1}{T}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{k}{4 m}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 97 Which of the following statements are TRUE for damped vibrations? P. For a system having critical damping, the value of damping ratio is unity and system does not undergo a vibratory motion. Q. Logarithmic decrement method is used to determine the amount of damping in a physical system. R. In case of damping due to dry friction between moving surfaces resisting force of constant magnitude acts opposite to the relative motion. S. For the case of viscous damping, drag force is directly proportional to the square of relative velocity.
