The gear(s) which act(s) as idler(s) is/are
solution: Only 5

question: Question 100 A single-degree-freedom spring-mass system is subjected to a sinusoidal force of 10 N amplitude and frequency [latex]\omega[/latex] along the axis of the spring. The stiffness of the spring is 150 N/m, damping factor is 0.2 and the undamped natural frequency is 10[latex]\omega[/latex].  At steady state, the amplitude of vibration (in m) is approximately
solution: [latex]A=\frac{F_{0} / s}{\sqrt{\left[1-\left(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}\right]^{2}+\left(2 \xi \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}}}[/latex] data given [latex] \begin{array}{c} F=10 \mathrm{N} \\ S=150 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \\ \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}=\frac{\omega}{10 \omega}=0.1 \\ \varepsilon=0.2 \\ \Rightarrow A=\frac{10 / 150}{\sqrt{\left[1-(0.1)^{2}\right]^{2}+[2 \times 0.2 \times 0.1]^{2}}}=0.07 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 101 In a certain slider-crank mechanism, lengths of crank and connecting rod are equal. If the crank rotates with a uniform angular speed of 14 rad/s and the crank length is 300 mm, the maximum acceleration of the slider (in m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex]) is ___________
solution: [latex]a=r \omega^{2}\left[\cos \theta+\frac{\cos 2 \theta}{n}\right] [/latex] [latex] \text{at} \quad \theta=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} a &\Rightarrow a_{\max } \\ a_{\max } &=r \omega^{2}\left[1+\frac{1}{n}\right] \\ n &=\frac{l}{r}=1 \\ a_{\max } &=2 r \omega^{2}=2 \times 0.3 \times 14^{2} \\ &=117.6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 102 In a spring-mass system, the mass is m and the spring constant is k. The critical damping coefficient of the system is 0.1 kg/s. In another spring-mass system, the mass is 2m and the spring constant is 8k. The critical damping coefficient (in kg/s) of this system is ____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \xi &=\frac{C}{2 \sqrt{m k}} \\ C &=2 \xi \sqrt{m k} \\ \frac{C_{2}}{C_{1}} &=\frac{2 \xi_{2} \sqrt{m_{2} k_{2}}}{2 \xi_{1} \sqrt{m_{1} k_{1}}} \\ \frac{C_{2}}{0.1} &=\frac{2 \times 1 \sqrt{2 m \times 8 k}}{2 \times 1 \sqrt{m \times k}} \\ C_{2} &=0.4 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 103 The number of degrees of freedom of the planetary gear train shown in the figure is
solution: Degree of freedom: [latex]F=3(l-1)-2 j-h [/latex] [latex] =3(4-1)-2 \times 3-1=2[/latex]

question: Question 104 A precision instrument package (m = 1 kg) needs to be mounted on a surface vibrating at 60 Hz. It is desired that only 5% of the base surface vibration amplitude be transmitted to the instrument. Assume that the isolation is designed with its natural frequency significantly lesser than 60 Hz, so that the effect of damping may be ignored. The stiffness (in N/m) of the required mounting pad is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given, } \omega&=2 \pi f=2 \pi \times 60 \\ \omega &=120 \pi \\ m &=1 \mathrm{kg} \\ \frac{F_{\mathrm{TR}}}{F_{0}} &=\frac{\sqrt{1+(2 \xi r)^{2}}}{\sqrt{\left(1-r^{2}\right)^{2}+(2 \xi r)^{2}}} \end{aligned}[/latex] No damping, [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \xi &=0 \\ \frac{F_{\mathrm{TR}}}{F_{0}} &=0.05 \\ 0.05 &=\frac{1}{r^{2}-1} \\ r^{2}-1 &=20 \\ r &=\sqrt{21} \\ \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}} &=\sqrt{21} \\ \frac{120 \pi}{\omega_{n}} &=\sqrt{21} \\ \omega_{n} &=82.266 \\ \sqrt{\frac{K}{m}} &=82.266 \\ \sqrt{\frac{K}{1}} &=6767.728 \\ K &=6767.72 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 105 Considering massless rigid rod and small oscillations, the natural frequency (in rad/s) of vibration of the system shown in the figure is
solution: [latex]Q \rightarrow [/latex] Change in angular positions of rod in anticlockwise direction. Restoring torque [latex]=(K r \theta)r[/latex] will act in clockwise direction [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau &=-K r^{2} \theta \\ l \alpha &=-K r^{2} \theta \\ \alpha &=-\frac{K r^{2}}{I} \theta \\ \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{K r^{2}}{I}} \\ I &=m\left(2 r^{2}\right)=1\left(4 r^{2}\right) \\ I &=\sqrt{\frac{400 \times r^{2}}{1 \times 4 r^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{400}{4}} \\ \omega_{n} &=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 106 Consider a slider crank mechanism with nonzero masses and inertia. A constant torque [latex]\tau[/latex]  is applied on the crank as shown in the figure. Which of the following plots best resembles variation of crank angle, [latex]\theta[/latex]  versus time
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau(\text { torque }) &=I \ddot{\theta} \\ \tau &=\text { constant } \\ I &=\text { constant } \\ \tau &=I \frac{d^{2} \theta}{d t^{2}} \\ \frac{d^{2} \theta}{d t^{2}} &=\frac{\tau}{I} \\ \frac{d \theta}{d t} &=\frac{\tau}{I} t+C_{1} \\ \theta &=\frac{\tau}{I} \frac{t^{2}}{2}+C_{1} t+C_{2}\\ \theta=f(t)&= \text{ parabolic function}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] But practically graph will be fluctuating about ideal  parabolic curve.

question: Question 107 A single degree of freedom system has a mass of 2 kg, stiffness 8 N/m and viscous damping  ratio 0.02. The dynamic magnification factor at an excitation frequency of 1.5 rad/s is  _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} M F&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left[1-\left(\frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right)^{2}\right]^{2}+\left[2 \zeta \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}\right]^{2}}}\\ \text{Given, } \omega&=1.5 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}=\sqrt{\frac{8}{2}}=2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \zeta &=0.02, \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}=\frac{1.5}{2}=0.75 \\ \therefore \quad M F &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left[1-(0.75)^{2}\right]^{2}+(2 \times 0.02 \times 0.75)^{2}}} \\ \therefore \quad M F &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{(0.4375)^{2}+(0.03)^{2}}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{0.1923}} \\ \therefore \quad M F &=2.28 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 108 Torque and angular speed data over one cycle for a shaft carrying a flywheel are shown in the figures. The moment of inertia (in kg.[latex]m^{2}[/latex]) of the flywheel is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I &=? \\ E &=3000 \times\left[\pi-\frac{\pi}{2}\right]-1500 \times[2 \pi-\pi] \\ &=3000 \times \frac{\pi}{2}-1500 \pi=0 \\ T_{\text {mean }} \times & 2 \pi=E \\ T_{\text {mean }} &=\frac{E}{2 \pi}=0 \\ \omega_{\min } &=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \mathrm{at} 0=\pi / 2 \\ \omega_{\max } &=20 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \mathrm{at} 0=\pi \\ C_{s} &=\frac{\omega_{\max }-\omega_{\min }}{\frac{\omega_{\max }+\omega_{\min }}{2}} \\ &=\frac{2\left\{\omega_{\max }-\omega_{\min }\right\}}{\omega_{\max }+\omega_{\min }} \\ &=\frac{2 \times\{20-10\}}{20+10}=0.67 \\ \Delta E &=3000 \times \frac{\pi}{2}=1500 \pi \\ \Delta E &=I \omega^{2} C_{s}\\ 1500 \pi &=I \times \omega_{\text {mean }}^{2} \times 0.67 \\ 1500 \pi &=I \times\left\{\frac{20+10}{2}\right\}^{2} \times 0.67 \\ I &=\frac{1500 \pi}{15^{2} \times 0.67}=31.26 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 109 It is desired to avoid interference in a pair of spur gears having a 20[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] pressure angle. With increase in pinion to gear speed ratio, the minimum number of teeth on the pinion
solution: For [latex]20^{\circ}[/latex] stub pressure angle spur gears pair minimum number of teeth on the pinion can be expressed as [latex]t_{min}=\frac{2A_p}{\sqrt{1+G(G+2)\sin ^2 \phi -1}}[/latex] Where, [latex]A_p:[/latex] Fractional addendum for one module in order to avoid interference. [latex]G:[/latex] Gear ration [latex]\phi :[/latex] Pressure angle Now we have given that speed ratio is increased & we know that; [latex]\text{Speed ratio}=\frac{1}{\text{gear ratio}}[/latex] So if gear ratio is increased we can say that minimum number of teeth on pinion must be increase to avoid interference.

question: Question 110 A point mass is executing simple harmonic motion with an amplitude of 10 mm and frequency of   4 Hz. The maximum acceleration (m/[latex]s^2[/latex]) of the mass is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_{n} &=\frac{\omega_{n}}{2 \times \pi} \\ \Rightarrow \omega_{n} &=2 \pi f=2 \times 3.14 \times 4=25.12 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ a_{\max } &=\omega_{n}^{2} x=(25.12)^{2} \times 10 \times 10^{-3} \\ &=6.31 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 111 In a statically determinate plane truss, the number of joints (j) and the number of members (m) are related by
solution: A simple truss is formed by enlarging the basic truss element which contains three members and three joints, by adding two additional members for each additional joint, so the total number of members m in a simple truss is given by [latex] m=3+2(j-3)=2 j-3[/latex] where m= number of members j= total number of joints (including those attached to the supports)

question: Question 112 A mass-spring-dashpot system with mass m = 10 kg, spring constant k = 6250 N/m is excited by a harmonic excitation of [latex]10 cos(25t)[/latex] N. At the steady state, the vibration amplitude of the mass is   40 mm. The damping coefficient (c, in N.s/m) of the dashpot is _______
solution:
[latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Given, } m=10 \mathrm{kg}, F_{0}=10 \mathrm{N} \\ \omega=25 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}, k=6250 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \\ X =\frac{F_{0}}{\sqrt{\left(k-m \omega^{2}\right)^{2}+(c \omega)^{2}}}\\ \text{or}\quad \sqrt{\left(k-m \omega^{2}\right)^{2}+(c \omega)^{2}}=\frac{F_{0}}{X} \\ \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} (c \omega) &=\sqrt{\left(\frac{F_{0}}{X}\right)^{2}-\left(k-m \omega^{2}\right)^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{\left(\frac{10}{0.04}\right)^{2}-(6250-10 \times 625)^{2}}\\c \omega &=\frac{10}{0.04}=250 \\
\therefore \quad c &=\frac{250}{\omega}=\frac{250}{25}=10 \mathrm{Ns} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned} [/latex]

question: Question 113 A slider-crank mechanism with crank radius 60 mm and connecting rod length 240 mm is shown in figure. The crank is rotating with a uniform angular speed of 10 rad/s, counter clockwise. For the given configuration, the speed (in m/s) of the slider is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} L=240\mathrm{mm}\\ r=60 \mathrm{mm} \\ n=\frac{L}{r}=\frac{240}{60}=4 \\ \omega=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex] From the given configuration, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \cos \theta=\frac{\sin \theta}{n} \text { or } \tan \theta=n\\ \text{or }\theta=\tan ^{-1} \\ \quad=75.96^{\circ} \\ \therefore \quad V_{s}=\omega r\left[\sin \theta+\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2 n}\right] \\ =10 \times 0.06\left[\sin 75.96^{\circ}+\frac{\sin 151.92^{\circ}}{2 \times 4}\right] \\ =0.6[0.97+0.0588] \\ =0.6 \times 1.0288\\ \text{or }V_{0}=\omega \end{array}[/latex] since slider is [latex] \perp [/latex] ar to the crank [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{so,} &=\omega r=10 \times 0.06 \\ &=0.6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 114 Consider a rotating disk cam and a translating roller follower with zero offset. Which one of the following pitch curves, parameterized by t, lying in the interval 0 to [latex]2\pi[/latex] , is associated with the maximum translation of the follower during one full rotation of the cam rotating about the center  at [latex](x,y)=(0,0)[/latex] ?
solution: Maximum translation of the follower during one full rotation about center will be [latex]d=\sqrt{x^2+y^2}\text{ where }d: \text{translation of follower}[/latex] and [latex]d_{max} \text{ at } \frac{d\;d(t)}{dt}=0[/latex] [latex]d_{max}:[/latex] Maximum translation of follower [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t)&=\frac{1}{2} + \cos t\\ y(t)&=2 \sin t \\ d &=\sqrt{\left (\frac{1}{2} + \cos t \right )^2 +(2 \sin t)^2} \\ &= \sqrt{\frac{1}{4}+ \cos t+ \cos ^2 t +4 \sin ^2 t}\\ &= \sqrt{\frac{5}{4}+\cos t +3 \sin ^2 t} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{For }d_{max}:\\ \frac{d(\cos t + 3 \sin ^2 t)}{dt}&=0\\ - \sin t +6 \sin t \cos t&=0\\ \cos t&=0\\ t=\frac{\pi}{2},\frac{3 \pi}{2}&\\ d_{max}=\sqrt{\frac{5}{4}+0+3}\\ =\sqrt{\frac{5+12}{4}}\\ =\sqrt{\frac{17}{4}}=2.06\\ d_{max}=2.06 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 115 The damping ratio of a single degree of freedom spring-mass-damper system with mass of 1 kg, stiffness 100 N/m and viscous damping coefficient of 25 N.s/m is _______
solution: Damping ratio [latex] \zeta=\frac{C}{2 \sqrt{k m}}=\frac{25}{2 \sqrt{1 \times 100}}=\frac{25}{20}=1.25[/latex]

question: Question 116 Gear 2 rotates at 1200 rpm in counter clockwise direction and engages with Gear 3. Gear 3 and Gear 4 are mounted on the same shaft. Gear 5 engages with Gear 4. The numbers of teeth on Gears 2, 3, 4 and 5 are 20, 40, 15 and 30, respectively. The angular speed of Gear 5 is
solution: [latex]\therefore [/latex] Angular speed of gear 5 [latex] =\frac{-20 \times 1200 \times 15}{40 \times 30}=-300 \mathrm{ rpm}[/latex] [latex] =300 \mathrm{ rpm}\quad [/latex]{counter clockwise}

question: Question 117 Consider a single degree-of-freedom system with viscous damping excited by a harmonic force. At resonance, the phase angle (in degree) of the displacement with respect to the exciting force is
solution: X:  Displacement [latex] F_{0}: [/latex] Excitation force [latex] c \omega X: [/latex] Damping force k X:  Spring force [latex] m \omega^{2} X: [/latex] Inertia force

question: Question 118 A rigid link PQ of length 2 m rotates about the pinned end Q with a constant angular acceleration of 12 rad/[latex]s^{2}[/latex] . When the angular velocity of the link is 4 rad/s, the magnitude of the resultant acceleration (in m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex] ) of the end P is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} a_{T} &=r \alpha=2 \times 12=24 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ a_{R} &=\omega^{2} r=16 \times 2=32 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ a &=\sqrt{a_{T}^{2}+a_{R}^{2}}=\sqrt{24^{2}+32^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{1600}=40 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 119 Maximum fluctuation of kinetic energy in an engine has been calculated to be 2600 J. Assuming that the engine runs at an average speed of 200 rpm, the polar mass moment of inertia (in kg.[latex]m^2[/latex]) of a flywheel to keep the speed fluctuation within [latex]\pm 0.5[/latex]% of the average speed is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta E &=2600 \mathrm{J} \\ N_{\text {average }} &=200 \mathrm{rpm} \\ I &=? \\ C_{s} &=\pm 0.5 \% \\ &=2 \times \frac{0.5}{100}=0.01 \\ \Delta E &=I \omega^{2} C_{s} \\ 2600 &=I \times\left\{\frac{2 \pi}{60} \times 200\right\}^{2} \times 0.01 \\ 2600 &=I \times 438.6491 \times 0.01 \\ I &=\frac{2600}{4.3865}=592.73 \mathrm{kgm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 120 What is the natural frequency of the spring mass system shown below? The contact between the block and the inclined plane is frictionless. The mass of the block is denoted by m and the spring constants are denoted by [latex]k_1 \; and \; k_2[/latex] as shown below.
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} m\ddot{x}+\left(k_{1}+k_{2}\right) x&=0 \\ \ddot{x}+\left(\frac{k_{1}+k_{2}}{m}\right) x&=0 \\ \therefore \qquad \omega_{n}&=\sqrt{\frac{k_{1}+k_{2}}{m}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 121 In vibration isolation, which one of the following statements is NOT correct regarding Transmissibility (T)?

options.A: T is nearly unity at small excitation frequencies
options.B: T can be always reduced by using higher damping at any excitation frequency

question: Question 122 A 4-bar mechanism with all revolute pairs has link lengths [latex]l_f[/latex]=20mm, [latex]l_{in}[/latex]=40mm, [latex]l_{co}[/latex]=50mm and [latex]l_{out}[/latex]=60mm. The suffixes 'f', 'in', 'co' and 'out' denote the fixed link, the input link, the coupler and output link respectively. Which one of the following statements is true about the input and output links?
solution: [latex]S+L \lt P+Q[/latex] In this case, shortest link is fixed and hence, the resulting mechanism is double crank mechanism.

question: Question 123 A rigid uniform rod AB of length L and mass m is hinged at C such that AC = L/3, CB = 2L/3. Ends A and B are supported by springs of spring constant k. The natural frequency of the system is given by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta &=\frac{y_{A}}{\left(\frac{L}{3}\right)}=\frac{y_{B}}{\left(\frac{2 L}{3}\right)} \\ I_{0} &=I_{C}+m\left(\frac{2 L}{3}-\frac{L}{2}\right)^{2} \\ I_{C} &=\frac{m L^{2}}{12} \\ \therefore \quad I_{0} &=\frac{m L^{2}}{12}+\frac{m L^{2}}{36}=\frac{m L^{2}}{9} \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking, [latex]\Sigma M_{0}=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow\left(k y_{A} \times \frac{L}{3}\right)+\left(k y_{B} \times \frac{2 L}{3}\right)+I_{0} \ddot{\theta}=0 \\ \Rightarrow k \theta\left(\frac{L}{3}\right)^{2}+k \theta\left(\frac{2 L}{3}\right)^{2}+\frac{m L^{2}}{9} \ddot{\theta}=0 \\ \Rightarrow\left(\frac{m L^{2}}{9}\right) \ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{5 k L^{2}}{9}\right) \theta=0 \\ \Rightarrow \ddot{\theta}+\left(\frac{5 k}{m}\right) \theta=0 \\ \omega_{n}^{2}=\frac{5 k}{m} \\ \quad \omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{5 k}{m}} \\ \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 124 An offset slider-crank mechanism is shown in the figure at an instant. Conventionally, the Quick Return Ratio (QRR) is considered to be greater than one. The value of QRR is _______
solution: Length of connecting rod: [latex]l_{r}=40 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Crank radius: [latex]r=20 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Eccentricity: [latex]e=10 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &\phi=\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{e}{l+r}\right)-\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{e}{l-r}\right) \\ &=\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{6}\right)-\cos ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=20.4^{\circ} \\ &\mathrm{QRR}=\frac{\text { Time of advance stroke }}{\text { Time of return stroke }} \\ &=\left(\frac{\theta_{C}}{2 \pi N}\right)\left(\frac{2 \pi N}{\theta_{R}}\right) \\ &\mathrm{QRR} =\frac{\theta_{C}}{\theta_{R}}=\frac{180^{\circ}+\phi}{180^{\circ}-\phi} \\ &=\frac{180^{\circ}+20.4^{\circ}}{180^{\circ}-20.4^{\circ}}=1.25 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 125 A slider crank mechanism has slider mass of 10 kg, stroke of 0.2 m and rotates with a uniform angular velocity of 10 rad/s. The primary inertia forces of the slider are partially balanced by a revolving mass of 6 kg at the crank, placed at a distance equal to crank radius. Neglect the mass of connecting rod and crank. When the crank angle (with respect to slider axis) is [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex] , the unbalanced force (in newton) normal to the slider axis is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \omega &=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \theta &=30^{\circ} \\ r &=\frac{s}{2}=0.1 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Unbalanced force }&=m \omega^{2} r \sin 30^{\circ} & \\ &=6 \times 100 \times 0.1 \times \frac{1}{2} \\ &=30 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 126 A rigid link PQ is 2 m long and oriented at [latex]20^{\circ}[/latex]  to the horizontal as shown in the figure.  The magnitude and direction of velocity [latex]V_{Q}[/latex] , and the direction of velocity [latex]V_{P}[/latex]  are given. The magnitude of [latex]V_{P}[/latex](in m/s) a t this instant is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \; \omega _{PQ}&=\frac{V_P}{PI_{PQ}}=\frac{V_Q}{QI_{PQ}} \\ PI_{PQ}&=\text{Distance between P and }I_{PQ} \\ &= 2 \cos 70^{\circ}+ 2 \sin 70^{\circ} \times \tan 45^{\circ}\\ QI_{PQ} &= \text{Distance between Q and }I_{PQ} \\ &=\sqrt{2}\times 2 \times \sin 70^{\circ} \\ &= 2.66m\\ \therefore \;\; \frac{V_P}{2.56} &=\frac{1}{2.66}\\ V_P&=\frac{2.56}{2.66}=0.96\; m/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 127 Critical damping is the
solution: The system with critical damping returns to equilibrium in fastest time without any oscillation. In critically damped free vibrations, the damping force is just sufficient to dissipate the energy within   One cycle of motion. The system never executes  a cycle, it approaches equilibrium with exponentially decaying displacement.

options.A: largest amount of damping for which no oscillation occurs in free vibration

options.D: smallest amount of damping for which the motion is simple harmonic in free vibration

question: Question 128 A compound gear train with gears P, Q, R and S has number of teeth 20, 40, 15 and 20, respectively. Gears Q and R are mounted on the same shaft as shown in the figure below. The diameter of the gear Q is twice that of the gear R. If the module of the gear R is 2 mm, the center distance in mm between gears P and S is
solution: Centre distance between P and S . [latex] (Radius) _{P}+(\text { Radius })_{Q}+(\text { Radius })_{R}+(\text { Radius })_{S}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad D_{Q}&=2 \times D_{R} \\ M_{R} &=2 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \quad M_{R}&=\frac{D_{R}}{T_{R}}\\ \therefore \quad D_{R}&=T \times M_{R} \\ &=15 \times 2=30 \mathrm{mm} \\ D_{Q} &=2 \times 30 \\ &=60 \mathrm{mm}\\ \text{and }\quad T_{Q}&=40\\ \therefore \quad M_{Q} &=\frac{D_{Q}}{T_{Q}} \\ &=\frac{60}{40}=1.5 \end{aligned}[/latex] since Q meshes with P module of gear Q is equal to module of gear P [latex] \begin{aligned} D_{P} &=M_{P} \times T_{P} \\ &=1.5 \times 20 \\ &=30.0 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] since Smeshes with R module of Sand R will be same [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \text{Module of }S&=2 \mathrm{mm} \\ D_{s} &=M_{s} \times T_{s}=2 \times 20 \\ &=40 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Centre distance [latex] \begin{aligned} &=15+30+15+20 \\ &=80 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 129 A flywheel connected to a punching machine has to supply energy of 400 Nm while running at a mean angular speed of 20 rad/s. If the total fluctuation of speed is not to exceed  [latex]\pm 2[/latex]%, the mass moment of inertia of the flywheel in [latex]kg-m^{2}[/latex]
  is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta E &=400 \mathrm{Nm} \\ \omega_{\text {mean }} &=20 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ C_{s} &=\pm 2 \% \\ &=2 \times \frac{2}{100}=0.04 \\ \Delta E &=I \omega_{\text {mean }}^{2} C_{s} \\ 400 &=I \times\{20\}^{2} \times\{0.04\} \\ \text{or}\quad I &=25 \mathrm{kgm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 130 A planar closed kinematic chain is formed with rigid links PQ = 2.0 m,  QR = 3.0 m,  RS = 2.5 m   and  SP = 2.7 m with all revolute joints. The link to be fixed to obtain a double rocker (rockerrocker) mechanism is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} P Q=2.0 \mathrm{m}, Q R=3.0 \mathrm{m}, R S=2.5 \mathrm{m} \\ S P=2.7 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex] (i) If shortest line PQ=2.0m is fixed, then we will give double crank. (ii) If link adjacent to shortest is fixed, then we will get crank-rocker mechanism. (iii) If we fix coupler 'RS', we will get double rocker mechanism.

question: Question 131 If two nodes are observed at a frequency of 1800 rpm during whirling of a simply supported long slender rotating shaft, the first critical speed of the shaft in rpm is
solution: First frequency [latex]=f_{n}[/latex] Second frequency [latex]=4 f_{n}[/latex] Third frequency [latex]=9 f_{n} [/latex] [latex] \therefore 1800=9 f_{n}[/latex](Considering 2 nodes between the ends) [latex] \Rightarrow \quad f_{n}=\frac{1800}{9}=200 \mathrm{rpm}[/latex]

question:
Question 132 A link OB is rotating with a constant angular velocity of  2 rad/s in counter clockwise direction and a block is sliding radially outward on it with an uniform velocity of  0.75 m/s with respect to the rod, as shown in the figure below. If OA = 1 m, the magnitude of the absolute acceleration of  the block at location A in [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex]
 is
solution: Acceleration of the block at [latex]A=\vec{a}_{c r}+\vec{a}_{r}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\overrightarrow{2 \omega V}+\overrightarrow{\omega^{2} r} \\ \Rightarrow \quad r&=O A\\ \Rightarrow \quad 2 \omega V&=2 \times 2 \times 0.75=3 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \omega^{2} r&=2^{2} \times 1=4 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] As coriolis component and radial component are  perpendicular to each other. So, [latex]\left|\vec{a}_{a b s}\right|=\sqrt{3^{2}+4^{2}}=5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question: Question 133 A concentrated mass m is attached at the centre of a rod length 2L as shown in the figure. The rod is kept in a horizontal equilibrium position by a spring of stiffness k. For very small amplitude of vibration, neglecting the weights of the rod and spring, the un-damped natural frequency of the system is
solution: Taking moments about O [latex]\begin{array}{l} k x \times 2 L=m g \times L \\ x=\frac{m g}{2 k} \end{array}[/latex] now [latex]\frac{x}{2 L}=\frac{\delta}{L}[/latex] (from similar triangles) [latex] \delta=\frac{x}{2}[/latex] Using static deflection of mass [latex] \omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{\delta}}=\sqrt{\frac{4 k}{m}}[/latex]

question: Question 134 In the mechanism given below, if the  angular velocity of the eccentric circular disc is 1 rad/s, the angular velocity (rad/s) of the follower  link for the instant shown in the figure is Note: All dimensions are in mm
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta P Q O &\sim \Delta S R O \\ \therefore \quad \frac{P Q}{S R}&=\frac{P O}{S O} \qquad\cdots(1) \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying Pythagoras theorem in [latex]\Delta PQO[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} (P O)^{2}&=(P Q)^{2}+(O Q)^{2}\\ \therefore \quad (P Q)&=\sqrt{(P O)^{2}-(O Q)^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{(50)^{2}-(25)^{2}}=43.3 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Putting value of P Q in Eq. (1), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{43.3}{S R} &=\frac{45+5}{5} \\ S R &=\frac{43.3 \times 5}{50}=4.33 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Velocity of Q is equal to velocity of R [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{Q} &=V_{R} \\ &=SR \times \omega \\ &=4.33 \times 1=4.33 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{s} \\ \omega_{P Q} &=\frac{V_{P Q}}{P Q}=\frac{4.33}{43.3}=0.1 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 135 The following are the data for two crossed helical gears used for speed reduction: Gear I: pitch circle diameter in the plane of rotation 80mm and helix angle [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex] Gear II: pitch circle diameter in the plane of rotation 120mm and helix angle [latex]22.5^{\circ}[/latex] If the input speed is 1440 rpm. The output speed in rpm is
solution: For helical gear [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Velocity ratio } &=\frac{N_{2}}{N_{1}}=\frac{D_{1} \cos \phi}{D_{2} \cos \phi} \\ &=\frac{80 \cos 30^{\circ}}{120 \cos 22.5^{\circ}}\\ \therefore \quad N_{2} &=1440 \times 0.625 \\ &=900 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 136 A disc of mass m is attached to a spring of stiffness k as shown in the figure. The disc rolls without slipping on a horizontal surface. The natural frequency of vibration of the system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I \ddot{\theta}+k x r &=0 \\ \left(\frac{m r^{2}}{2}+m r^{2}\right) \ddot{\theta}+k(r \cdot \theta) r &=0 \\ \frac{3}{2} m r^{2} \ddot{\theta}+k r^{2} \theta &=0 \\ \ddot{\theta}+\frac{2 k}{3 m} \theta &=0 \\ \text { Natural frequency } &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{2 k}{3 m}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 137 A mass of 1kg is attached to two identical springs each with stiffness k = 20kN/m as shown in the figure. Under frictionless condition, the natural frequency of the system in Hz is close to
solution: since springs are in parallel hence [latex] \begin{aligned} K_{\text {equivalent }} &=K+K=2 K \\ \therefore \quad \text { Frequency } &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{2 K}{m}} \\ &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{2 \times 20 \times 10^{3}}{1}} \\ &=31.83 \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 138 For the four-bar linkage shown in the figure, the angular velocity of link AB is 1 rad/s. the length of link CD is 1.5 times the length of link AB. In the configuration shown, the angular velocity of link CD in rad/s is
solution: From angular velocity ratio theorem, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\omega_{CD}}{\omega_{AB}}&=\frac{AB}{CD} \\ \frac{\omega_{CD}}{1}&=\frac{1}{1.5} \\ {\omega_{CD}}&=\frac{2}{3}\;rad/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 139 A double - parallelogram mechanism is shown in the figure. Note that PQ is a single link. The mobility of the mechanism is
solution: This  is a special case because the link between & parallel to P and Q is redundant as its presence does not effect the mechanism. Hence the DOF is 1.

question:
Question 140 For the configuration shown, the angular velocity of link AB is 10 rad/s counterclockwise. The magnitude of the relative sliding velocity (in [latex]ms^{-1}[/latex]
) of slider B with respect to rigid link CD is
solution: As AB is perpendicular to slider for given condition, so sliding velocity of slider equals to velocity of link AB [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\omega \times A B \\ =10 \times 0.25=2.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 141 For the epicyclic gear arrangement shown in the figure, [latex]\omega _{2}=100rad/s[/latex]
 clockwise (CW) and [latex]\omega _{arm}=80rad/s[/latex]
 counter clockwise (CCW). The angular velocity [latex]\omega _{5}(in rad/s)[/latex]
 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given, } N+y &=+100(\mathrm{c} . \mathrm{w}) \\ y &=-80 \\ \therefore \quad N-80 &=100 \\ N &=180\\ \therefore \quad w_{s} &=\frac{-N}{3}+y \\ &=-60-80=-140 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 142 A mass m attached to a spring is subjected to a harmonic force as shown in  figure. The amplitude of the forced motion is observed to be 50mm. The value of m (in kg) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given, } \qquad F(t) &=100 \cos (100 t) N \\ F_{0} &=100 \mathrm{N} \\ \omega &=100 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ K &=3000 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Amplitude: } \qquad X &=50 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}\\ \text{Now by } \qquad x&=\frac{F_{0}}{\left(K-m \omega^{2}\right)} \end{aligned}[/latex] as damping is zero. [latex] \begin{aligned} K-m \omega^{2} &=\frac{100}{50 \times 10^{-3}}=2000 \\ m \omega^{2} &=3000-2000 \\ m &=\frac{1000}{(100)^{2}}=0.1 \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 143 Tooth interference in an external involute spur gear pair can be reduced by
solution: When gear teeth are produced by a generating process, interference is automatically eliminated because the cutting tool removes the interfering portion of the flank. This effect is called undercutting. By undercutting the undercut tooth can be considerably weakened. So, interference can be reduced by using more teeth on the gear. However, if the gears are to transmit a given amount of power, more teeth can be used only by increasing the pitch diameter.

options.A: decreasing center distance between gear pair

question:
Question 144 The natural frequency of a spring-mass system on earth is [latex]\omega _{n}[/latex]. The natural frequency of this system on the moon [latex](g_{moon}= g_{earth}/6)[/latex]
is
solution: [latex]\omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}[/latex]

question: Question 145 Which of the following statements is INCORRECT?
solution: Grashof's rule states that for a planar crank rocker four bar mechanism, the sum of shortest and longest link length is less than the sum of remaining two link length i.e. [latex] s+l \leq p+q[/latex]

options.A: Grashof's rule states that for a planar crank-rocker four bar mechanism, the sum of the shortest and longest link lengths cannot be less than the sum of the remaining two link lengths.
options.B: Inversions of a mechanism are created by fixing different links one at a time.
options.C: Geneva mechanism is an intermittent motion device
options.D: Gruebler's criterion assumes mobility of a planar mechanism to be one.

question: Question 146 There are two points P and Q on a planar rigid body. The relative velocity between the two points
solution: [latex]V_{P Q}=[/latex]  Relative velocity between P and Q. [latex] V_{P Q}=V_{P}-V_{Q} [/latex]Always perpendicular to PQ.

options.C: should always be perpendicular to PQ

question: Question 147 Mobility of a statically indeterminate structure is
solution: Mobility or degree of freedom for a statically indeterminate structure is always less than zero. i.e.,[latex]F \lt 0 [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] only option (A) is negative value [latex] \therefore F \leq-1[/latex]

question: Question 148 Match the approaches given below to perform stated kinematics / dynamics analysis of machine.
solution: 1. D' Alembert's principle [latex] \longrightarrow [/latex] Dynamic-static analysis 2. Grubler's criterion [latex] \longrightarrow [/latex] Mobility (for plane mechanism) 3. Grashoff's law [latex] \longrightarrow [/latex] Continuous relative rotation 4. Kennedy's theorem [latex] \longrightarrow [/latex] Velocity and acceleration

question: Question 149 A vehicle suspension system consists of a spring and a damper. The stiffness of the spring is 3.6kN/m and the damping constant of the damper is 400Ns/m. If the mass is 50kg, then the damping factor (d) and damped natural frequency (fn), respectively, are
solution: Stiffness of spring: [latex] K=3.6 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} [/latex] Damping constant of the damper [latex] \begin{array}{l} C=400 \mathrm{Ns} / \mathrm{m}\\ \text { Mass, } \quad m=50 \mathrm{kg} \\ m\ddot{x}+c \dot{x}+K x=0 \end{array}[/latex] [Suspension system consisting spring and damper] Damping factor [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{(d) or}\;\xi\;&=\frac{C}{C_{C}}=\frac{C}{2 \sqrt{K m}} \\ &=\frac{400 \mathrm{Ns} / \mathrm{m}}{2 \sqrt{3.6 \times 10^{3} \times 50 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \times \mathrm{kg}}} \\ &=0.471 \end{aligned}[/latex] Natural frequency, [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}=\sqrt{\frac{3.6 \times 10^{3}}{50}} \\ &=8.485 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Damped natural frequency, [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega_{d} &=\omega_{n} \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}=8.485 \sqrt{1-(0.471)^{2}} \\ 2 \pi f_{d} &=\omega_{d}=7.48 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ f_{d} &=1.19 \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 150 An automotive engine weighing 240kg is supported on four springs with linear characteristics. Each of the front two springs have a stiffness of 16MN/m while the stiffness of each rear spring is 32MN/m. The engine speed (in rpm), at which resonance is likely to occur, is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} K_{1}=K_{2}=16 \mathrm{MN} / \mathrm{m}=16 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \\ K_{3}=K_{4}=32 \mathrm{MN} / \mathrm{m}=32 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex] All the springs are in parallel combination. Therefore, Equivalent stiffness, [latex] \begin{aligned} K_{\mathrm{eq}} &=K_{1}+K_{2}+K_{3}+K_{4} \\ &=16+16+32+32 \\ &=96 \mathrm{MN} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] At resonance [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega &=\omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}} \\ \frac{2 \pi N}{60} &=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}=\sqrt{\frac{96 \times 10^{6} N / m}{240 \mathrm{kg}}} \\ N &=6042.5 \mathrm{rpm} \approx 6040 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 151 An epicyclic gear train is shown schematically in the figure The sun gear 2 on the input shaft is a 20 teeth external gear. The planet gear 3 is a 40 teeth external gear. The ring gear 5 is a 100 teeth internal gear. The ring gear 5 is fixed and the gear 2 is rotating at 60 rpm ccw (ccw=counter-clockwise and cw=clockwise) The arm 4 attached to the output shaft will rotate at
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{-N}{5}+y &=0 \quad[\text { Gear 5 is fixed }] \\ N+y & =-60 \quad \text { [counter clockwise }] \\ N+\frac{N}{5}& =-60 \\ \frac{6 N}{5}&=-60\\ N&=-50 \\ y&=+\frac{50}{5}=10 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Positive sign is taken clockwise hence arm rolate at +10 rpm clockwise.

question: Question 152 The rotor shaft of a large electric motor supported between short bearings at both deflection of 1.8mm in the middle of the rotor. Assuming the rotor to be perfectly balanced and supported at knife edges at both the ends, the likely critical speed (in rpm) of the shaft is
solution: Critical or whirling speed, [latex] \omega_{c}=\omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{K}{m}}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{\delta}} \mathrm{Hz}[/latex] If [latex]N_{c}[/latex] is the critical or whirling speed in rpm then [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{2 \pi N_{c}}{60} &=\sqrt{\frac{g}{\delta}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{2 \pi N_{c}}{60} &=\sqrt{\frac{9.81 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}}{1.8 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad N_{c}&=705.32 \mathrm{rpm} \approx 705 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 153 A simple quick return mechanism is shown in the figure. The forward to return ratio of the quick return mechanism is 2:1. If the radius of the crank [latex]O_{1}P[/latex]
 is 125 mm, then the distance 'd' (in mm) between the crank centre to lever pivot centre point should be
solution: [latex]O_{1} P=125 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] Quick Return Mechanism [latex] \frac{\text { Time of working (Forward) stroke }}{\text { Time of return stroke }} =\frac{\beta}{\alpha}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{360-\alpha}{\alpha} \\ \frac{2}{1} &=\frac{360^{\circ}-\alpha}{\alpha}\\ \Rightarrow \quad 2 \alpha&=360^{\circ}-\alpha \\ \Rightarrow \quad 3 \alpha&=360^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \alpha&=120^{\circ}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\alpha}{2}&=60^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] The extreme position of the crank [latex] \left(O_{1} P\right)[/latex] are shown in figure. From right angle triangle [latex] O_{2} O_{1} P_{1}, [/latex] we find that [latex] \begin{aligned} \sin \left(90^{\circ}-\alpha / 2\right) &=\frac{O_{1} P_{1}}{O_{1} O_{2}} \\ \sin \left(90^{\circ}-60^{\circ}\right) &=\frac{125}{O_{1} O_{2}}=\frac{125}{d} \\ \sin 30^{\circ} &=\frac{125}{d}\\ \text{or} \quad d&=\frac{125}{\sin 30^{\circ}}=250 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 154 A uniform rigid rod of mass m = 1kg and length L = 1m is hinged at its centre and laterally
supported at one end by a spring of spring constant k = 300 N/m. The natural frequency [latex]\omega _n[/latex] in
rad/s is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \frac{1}{2} I \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}=\text { constant } \\ \frac{1}{2} I \dot{\theta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k\left(\frac{L}{2} \theta\right)^{2}=\text { constant } \end{array}[/latex] Differentiating the whole expression w.rt. [latex] \frac{1}{2} I 2 \ddot{\theta} \ddot{\theta}+\frac{k}{2} \times \frac{L^{2}}{4} \times 2 \theta \dot{\theta}=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow I \ddot{\theta}+\frac{K L^{2}}{4} \theta=0[/latex] Putting the value of [latex]I=\frac{m L^{2}}{12} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow \frac{m L^{2}}{12} \ddot{\theta}+\frac{k L^{2}}{4} \theta=0 \\ \Rightarrow \ddot{\theta}+\frac{3 k}{m} \theta=0 \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Natural frequency: [latex]\omega_{x}=\sqrt{\frac{3 k}{m}} [/latex] [latex] =\sqrt{\frac{3 \times 300}{1}}=30 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question:
Question 155 In a cam design, the rise motion is given by a simple harmonic motion (SHM) [latex]s=\frac{h}{2}(1-cos\frac{\pi \theta }{\beta })[/latex] where h is total rise,
[latex]\theta[/latex] is camshaft angle, [latex]\beta[/latex] is the total angle of the rise interval. The jerk is given by
solution: The jerk is given by [latex]\frac{d^{3} s}{d t^{3}} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \text { if } S=\frac{h}{2}\left(1-\cos \frac{\pi \theta}{\beta}\right) \\ \therefore \quad \frac{d^{3} s}{d t^{3}}=-\frac{\pi^{3}}{\beta^{3}} \frac{h}{2} \sin \left(\frac{\pi \theta}{\beta}\right)\\ \text{where } \theta=\omega t \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 156 The natural frequency of the spring mass system shown in the figure is closest to
solution: springs are in parallel connection [latex] \begin{array}{l} \therefore K_{\mathrm{eq}}=K_{1}+K_{2}=4000+1600=5600 \\ \omega=\sqrt{\frac{5600}{1.4}}=\sqrt{4000} \\ f=\frac{\omega}{2 \pi}=\frac{\sqrt{4000}}{2 \pi}=10 \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 157 A Planar mechanism has 8 links and 10 rotary joints. The number of degrees of freedom of the
mechanism, using Grubler's criterion is
solution: Degree of freedom is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} &=3(l-1)-2 j-h\\ \text{Here, }\quad h &=\text { No. of higher pair }=0 \\ &=3(8-1)-(2 \times 10)=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 158 A cantilever type gate hinged at Q is shown in the figure. P and R are the centers of gravity of the cantilever part and the counterweight respectively. The mass of the cantilever part is 75 kg. The mass of the counterweight, for static balance, is
solution: Let counterweight at R is m kg For static condition [latex] \begin{aligned} \Sigma M_{Q} &=0 \\ m \times 0.5 &=75 \times 2 \\ m &=300 \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 159 A quick return mechanism is shown below. The crank OS is driven at 2 rev/s in counter - clockwise direction. The angular speed of PQ in rev/s when the block R attains maximum speed during forward stroke (stroke with slower speed) is
solution: Maximum speed during forward stroke occur when QR and QS are perpendicular. [latex] \begin{aligned} V &=250 \times 2=750 \times \omega P Q \\ \omega_{P Q} &=\frac{2}{3} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 160 A quick return mechanism is shown below. The crank OS is driven at 2 rev/s in counter - clockwise direction. If the quick return ratio is 1:2, then the length of the crank in mm is
solution: Given : [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{2 \theta}{2 \pi-2 \theta} &=\frac{1}{2}\\ \therefore \theta &=\frac{\pi}{3}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] In triangle OMP [latex] \begin{aligned} \cos \theta &=\frac{r}{O P} \\ \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) &=\frac{r}{500}\\ \text{or }r&=250 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 161 The equation of motion of a harmonic oscillator is given by [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} x}{\mathrm{d} t^{2}}+2\zeta \omega _{n}\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}+\omega _{n}^{2}x=0[/latex] and the initial conditions at t = 0 are x (0)= X, [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}(0)=0[/latex]. 
 The amplitude of x(t) after n complete cycle is
solution: We have, [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} ^2x}{\mathrm{d} t^2}+2\zeta \omega_n\frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{d} t}+\omega_n^2 x=0[/latex] [latex]\ddot x+2\zeta \omega_n\dot x+\omega_n^2 x=0[/latex] Logarithmic decrement is given by [latex]\delta=\ln\left ( \frac{x_1}{x_2} \right )=\frac{2\pi \zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}}[/latex] Logarithmic decrement for n cycle is given by [latex]\delta=\frac{1}{n}\ln\left ( \frac{x_1}{x_{n+1}} \right )[/latex] Given that, Initially amplitude is [latex]x_1=X[/latex] and we need to find amplitude after n cycle, so we have [latex]\frac{1}{n}\ln\left ( \frac{X}{x_{n+1}} \right )=\frac{2\pi \zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}}[/latex] [latex]\frac{X}{x_{n+1}} =e^{\frac{2\pi n\zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}}}[/latex] [latex]x_{n+1} =Xe^{-\frac{2\pi n\zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}}}[/latex]

question: Question 162 The natural frequency of the system shown below is
solution: Equivalent stiffness [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{k_{e q}} &=\frac{1}{\frac{k}{2}+\frac{k}{2}}+\frac{1}{k} \\ \therefore \quad k_{e q} &=k / 2 \end{aligned}[/latex] Now natural frequency [latex] =\sqrt{\frac{k_{e q}}{m}}=\sqrt{\frac{k}{2 m}}[/latex]

question:
Question 163 The speed of an engine varies from 210 rad/s to 190 rad/s. During a cycle the change in kinetic energy is found to be 400 Nm. The inertia of the flywheel in [latex]kgm^{2}[/latex]
 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \omega_{\min } &=190 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \omega_{\max } &=210 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \Delta E &=400 \mathrm{Nm} \\ C_{s} &=\frac{\omega_{\max }-\omega_{\min }}{\frac{\left(\omega_{\max }+\omega_{\min }\right)}{2}} \\ C_{s} &=\frac{210-190}{\frac{(210+190)}{2}}=\frac{20}{200}=0.1 \\ \omega_{\text {mean }} &=\frac{\omega_{\min }+\omega_{\max }}{2}=\frac{190+210}{2} \\ &=200 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \Delta E &=I \omega_{\text {mean }}^{2} C_{s} \\ 400 &=I \times(200)^{2} \times 0.1 \\ I &=\frac{400}{200^{2} \times 0.1}=0.1 \mathrm{kgm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 164 The input link [latex]O_2P[/latex] of a four bar linkage is rotated at 2 rad/s in counter clockwise direction as shown below. The angular velocity of the coupler PQ in rad/s, at an instant when [latex]\angle O_{4}O_{2}P=180^{\circ}[/latex]
, is
solution: When [latex] \angle O_{4} O_{2} P=180^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Now.}\quad \frac{\omega_{3}}{\omega_{2}}&=\frac{I_{12} I_{23}}{I_{13} I_{23}}=\frac{a}{2 a} \\ \frac{\omega_{3}}{2}&=\frac{1}{2} \\ \omega_{3}&=1 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 165 For an under damped harmonic oscillator, resonance
solution:
For under damped harmonic oscillator condition for resonance.
[latex]\omega_{d}=\omega_{n}[/latex]

options.A: occurs when excitation frequency is greater than undamped natural frequency
options.B: occurs when excitation frequency is less than undamped natural frequency

question: Question 166 A vibratory system consists of a mass 12.5 kg, a spring of stiffness 1000 N/m, and a dashpot with damping coefficient of 15 Ns/m. The value of logarithmic decrement is:
solution: [latex]\xi=\frac{c}{2 \sqrt{k m}}=\frac{15}{223.6}=0.0671[/latex] Logarithmic decrement [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{2 \pi \xi}{\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}}}=\frac{2 \pi \times 0.0671}{\sqrt{\left(1-(0.0671)^{2}\right.}} \\ =0.422 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 167 A vibratory system consists of a mass 12.5 kg, a spring of stiffness 1000 N/m, and a dashpot with damping coefficient of 15 Ns/m. The value of critical damping of the system is:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given: } & m=12.5 \mathrm{kg} \\ & k=1000 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \\ & c=15 \mathrm{Ns} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Critical damping, [latex] \begin{array}{l} =2 \sqrt{k m}=2 \sqrt{1000 \times 12.5} \\ =223.6 \mathrm{Ns} / \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 168 A planetary gear train has four gears and one carrier. Angular velocities of the gears are [latex]\omega _{1}[/latex],
[latex]\omega _{2}[/latex],
[latex]\omega _{3}[/latex] 
and [latex]\omega _{4}[/latex]
 respectively. The carrier rotates with angular velocity [latex]\omega _{5}[/latex] For [latex]\omega _{1}=60[/latex]
rpm clockwise (cw) when looked from the left, what is the angular velocity of the carrier and its direction so that Gear 4 rotates in counterclockwise (ccw) direction at twice the angular velocity of Gear 1 when looked from the lef
solution: Given: [latex] N_{1}+y=+60 \qquad \left[\omega_{1}=60\right][/latex] Also [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{N_{1}}{6}+y &=-2\left(N_{1}+y\right) \qquad [\omega_{4}=-2\omega_{1}]\\ \therefore \quad \frac{N_{1}}{6}+y &=-2 N_{1}-2 y \\ \frac{N_{1}}{6}+2 N_{1} &=-3 y \\ \frac{13 N_{1}}{6} &=-3 y \\ N_{1}&=60-y \text { from }  \text { Eq. }(1) \\ \frac{13}{6}[60-y] &=-3 y \\ 780-13 y &=-18 y \\ 780 &=-18 y+13 y \\ 780 &=-5 y \\ y &=-\frac{780}{5}=-156 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Negative sign represents counter clockwise direction.

question:
Question 169 A planetary gear train has four gears and one carrier. Angular velocities of the gears are [latex]\omega _{1}[/latex],
[latex]\omega _{2}[/latex],
[latex]\omega _{3}[/latex] 
and [latex]\omega _{4}[/latex]
 respectively. The carrier rotates with angular velocity [latex]\omega _{5}[/latex] What is the relation between the angular velocities of Gear 1 and Gear 4?
solution: Therefore [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega_{1} &=N_{1}+y \\ \omega_{2} &=\frac{-15 N_{1}}{45}+y=\frac{-N_{1}}{3}+y \\ \omega_{3} &=\frac{-15 N_{1}}{45}+y=\frac{-N_{1}}{3}+y \\ \omega_{4} &=\frac{20 \times 15 \times N_{1}}{45 \times 40}+y=\frac{N_{1}}{6}+y \\ \therefore \frac{\omega_{1}-\omega_{5}}{\omega_{4}-\omega_{5}} &=\frac{N_{1}+y-y}{\frac{N_{1}}{6}+y-y}=\frac{N_{1}}{N_{1 / 6}}=6 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 170 In a four-bar linkage, S denotes the shortest link length, L is the longest link length, P and Q are the lengths of other two links. At least one of the three moving links will rotate by 360[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] if
solution: According to Grashof's law for a four bar mechanism. The sum of shortest and longest link lengths should not be greater than the sum of the  remaining two link length. i.e., [latex] \quad S+L \leq P+Q [/latex]

question: Question 171 A machine of 250 kg mass is supported on springs of total stiffness 100 kN/m. Machine has an unbalanced rotating force of 350 N at speed of 3600 rpm. Assuming a damping factor of 0.15, the value of transmissibility ratio is:
solution: [latex]\omega=\frac{2 \pi \times 3600}{60}=377 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] Natural frequency [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}=\sqrt{\frac{100 \times 1000}{250}}=20 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \text { Now, } \quad r &=\frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}}=\frac{377}{20}=18.85 \end{aligned}[/latex] Transmissibility ratio, [latex] \begin{aligned} \mathrm{TR} &=\frac{\sqrt{1+(2 \xi r)^{2}}}{\sqrt{\left(1-r^{2}\right)^{2}+(2 \xi r)^{2}}} \\ &=\frac{\sqrt{1+(2 \times 0.15 \times 18.85)^{2}}}{\sqrt{\left.1-(18.85)^{2}\right)+(2 \times 0.15 \times 18.85)^{2}}} \\ &=0.0162 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 172 Match the items in columns I and II
solution: (P) Higher kinematic pair - Line contact (Q) Lower kinematic pair - Surface contact (R) Quick return mechanism - Shaper (S) Mobility of a linkage - Grubler's equation

question:
Question 173 If [latex]C_{f}[/latex]
 is the coefficient of speed fluctuation of a flywheel then the ratio of [latex]\omega _{max}/\omega _{min}[/latex]
 will be:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C_{f} &=\frac{\omega_{\max }-\omega_{\min }}{\frac{\omega_{\max }+\omega_{\min }}{2}} \\ C_{f} &=\frac{2\left(\omega_{\max }-\omega_{\min }\right)}{\omega_{\max }+\omega_{\min }} \\ \frac{C_{f}}{2} &=\frac{\omega_{\max }-\omega_{\min }}{\omega_{\max }+\omega_{\min }} \\ C_{f} \omega_{\max }+C_{f} \omega_{\min } &=2 \omega_{\max }-2 \omega_{\min } \\ C_{f} \omega_{\min }+2 \omega_{\min } &=2 \omega_{\max }-C_{f} \omega_{\max } \\ \left(C_{f}+2\right) \omega_{\min } &=\omega_{\max }\left(2-C_{s}\right) \\ \frac{C_{f}+2}{2-C_{f}} &=\frac{\omega_{\max }}{\omega_{\min }} \\ \text { or } \quad \frac{\omega_{\max }}{\omega_{\min }} &=\frac{2+C_{f}}{2-C_{f}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 176 The differential equation governing the vibrating system is:
solution: Differential equation governing the above vibration system is given by [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow \frac{m d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}+C\left(\frac{d x}{d t}-\frac{d y}{d t}\right)+k x=0 \\ \Rightarrow m \ddot{x}+c(\dot{x}-\dot{y})+k x=0 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 177 For a four-bar linkage in toggle position, the value of mechanical advantage is:
solution: [latex]\omega_{4} [/latex] of the output link DC becomes zero at the extreme positions. The extreme positions of the linkage are known as "Toggle position". [latex] \therefore [/latex] Mechanical advantage [latex] =\frac{\omega_{\text {input }}}{\omega_{\text {output }}} [/latex] [latex] \because \quad \omega_{\text {output }}=0 [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Mechanical advantage [latex] =\infty[/latex]

question:
Question 178 At this instant, the angular velocity and angular acceleration of link [latex]O_{2}A[/latex]
 are [latex]\omega[/latex]=8rad/s and [latex]\alpha[/latex]=0, respectively, and the driving torque ([latex]\tau[/latex]) is zero. The link [latex]O_{2}A[/latex]
 is balanced so that its center of mass falls at [latex]O_{2}[/latex]. At the same instant, if the component of the force at joint A along AB is 30 N, then the magnitude of the joint reaction at [latex]O _{2}[/latex]
solution: Given: [latex] \omega = 8 , \text{rad/s}, \quad \alpha = 0, \quad O_2A = 60 , \text{mm} = 0.06 , \text{m} [/latex] [latex] \text{Force along AB at A} = 30 , \text{N} [/latex] Since [latex] \alpha = 0 [/latex] and the center of mass is at [latex] O_2 [/latex], no moment is acting. However, due to rotation, there is centripetal (radial) acceleration acting on point A: Step 1: Centripetal acceleration of point A [latex] a_c = \omega^2 r = 8^2 \times 0.06 = 64 \times 0.06 = 3.84 , \text{m/s}^2 [/latex] The inertial force at A due to rotation is: [latex] F = m a_c = 3.84m , \text{N} [/latex] (acting horizontally) Step 2: Total force at [latex] O_2 [/latex] Given vertical component = 30 N (along AB) Horizontal component = [latex] 3.84m [/latex] Total reaction: [latex] R = \sqrt{(3.84m)^2 + 30^2} [/latex] Now, from options, if we assume: [latex] 3.84m = 72 \Rightarrow m = \frac{72}{3.84} = 18.75 , \text{kg} [/latex] Then, [latex] R = \sqrt{72^2 + 30^2} = \sqrt{5184 + 900} = \sqrt{6084} = 78 , \text{N} [/latex] Answer: [latex] \boxed{\text{(C) 78 N}} [/latex]

options.D: cannot be determined from the given data

question:
Question 179 An instantaneous configuration of a four-bar mechanism, whose plane is horizontal, is shown in the figure below. At this instant, the angular velocity and angular acceleration of link [latex]O_{2}A[/latex]
 are [latex]\omega[/latex]=8rad/s and [latex]\alpha[/latex]=0, respectively, and the driving torque ([latex]\tau[/latex]) is zero. The link [latex]O_{2}A[/latex]
 is balanced so that its center of mass falls at [latex]O_{2}[/latex]. At the instant considered, what is the magnitude of the angular velocity of [latex]O_{4}B[/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \theta&=\frac{160-60}{240}=\frac{60}{\mathrm{CO}_{2}} \\ \therefore \quad \mathrm{CO}_{2}&= 144 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { Now, } \quad \frac{\omega_{4}}{\omega_{2}}&= \frac{I_{12} I_{24}}{I_{14} I_{24}}=\frac{144}{(240+144)} \\ \frac{\omega_{4}}{8}&=\frac{144}{384} \\ \therefore \quad \omega_{4}&=\frac{144}{384} \times 8=3 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 180 An instantaneous configuration of a four-bar mechanism, whose plane is horizontal, is shown in the figure below. At this instant, the angular velocity and angular acceleration of link [latex]O_{2}A[/latex]
 are [latex]\omega[/latex]=8rad/s and [latex]\alpha[/latex]=0, respectively, and the driving torque ([latex]\tau[/latex]) is zero. The link [latex]O_{2}A[/latex]
 is balanced so that its center of mass falls at [latex]O_{2}[/latex]. Which kind of 4-bar mechanism is [latex]O_{2}ABO_{4}[/latex]
?
solution: Length of link [latex] \begin{aligned} A B &=\sqrt{(240)^{2}+(160-60)^{2}} \\ &=l_{A B}=260 \mathrm{mm} \\ &=l_{A O_{2}}+l_{0_{2} O_{4}} \lt l_{A B}+l_{B O_{4}} \end{aligned}[/latex] and [latex]O_{2} O_{4} [/latex] is fixed link. Hence it will acts as crankrocker mechanism.

question: Question 181 In a spring-mass system, the mass is 0.1 kg and the stiffness of the spring is 1 kN/m. By introducing a damper, the frequency of oscillation is found to be 90% of the original value. What is the damping coefficient of the damper?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given }\quad \omega_{d}&=0.9 \omega_{n} \\ &\text{we know that}\\ \omega_{d} &=\omega_{n} \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.9 \omega_{n} &=\omega_{n} \sqrt{1-\xi^{2}} \\ \therefore \quad \xi &=0.436 \\ \text { Now } \quad \xi &=\frac{c}{2 \sqrt{k m}} \\ \therefore \quad c &=2 \times 0.436 \times \sqrt{1000 \times 0.1} \\ &=8.71 \mathrm{Ns} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 182 A rotating disc of 1 m diameter has two eccentric masses of 0.5 kg each at radii of 50 mm and 60 mm at angular positions of 0[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] and 150[latex]^{\circ}[/latex], respectively. A balancing mass of 0.1 kg is to be used to balance the rotor. What is the radial position of the balancing mass?
solution: Let x and y is position of balancing mass along x and y directions. Resolving forces along x-axis [latex] \begin{array}{l} 0.5\left(-60 \times 10^{-3} \cos 30^{\circ}+50 \times \cos 0 \times 10^{-3}\right) \omega^{2} \\ =0.1 \times x \times 10^{-3}\\ \therefore \quad x=-9.8 \mathrm{mm} \\ 0.5 \times\left(60 \times 10^{-3} \times \sin 30\right) \omega^{2}+0.5(50 \times 10^{-3}\\ \qquad \qquad \times \sin0) \omega^{2}=0.1\omega^{2}y\\ \therefore \quad y=150 \mathrm{mm} \end{array}[/latex] Position of balancing mass, [latex] \begin{aligned} r &=\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}} \\ &=150.3 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}=\sqrt{(-9.8)^{2}+(150)^{2}}[/latex]

question: Question 183 In a cam-follower mechanism, the follower needs to rise through 20 mm during 60[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] of cam rotation, the first 30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] with a constant acceleration and then with a deceleration of the same magnitude. The initial and final speeds of the follower are zero. The cam rotates at a uniform speed of 300 rpm. The maximum speed of the follower is
solution: Angular velocity, [latex] \omega=\frac{2 \pi N}{60}=\frac{2 \pi 300}{60}=10 \pi[/latex] Time taken to move [latex]30^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{\frac{\pi}{180} \times 30}{\omega}=\frac{\frac{\pi}{6}}{10 \pi}=\frac{1}{60} \mathrm{s}[/latex] During this time, follower moves by distance of 10mm with initial velocity [latex] \begin{aligned} u&=0\\ \text{Now;} \quad S &=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2} \\ 0.01 &=0+\frac{1}{2} \times a \times\left(\frac{1}{60}\right)^{2} \\ \therefore \quad a &=0.01 \times 2 \times(60)^{2}\\ &=72 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ V_{\max } &=U+a t\\ &=0+72 \times \frac{1}{60}=1.20 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 184 There are four samples P, Q, R and S, with natural frequencies 64, 96, 128 and 256 Hz respectively. There are mounted on test setups for conducting vibration experiments. If a loud pure note of frequency 144 Hz is produced by some instrument, which of the samples will show the most perceptible induced vibration?
solution: since the natural frequency of R(128Hz) is close to the frequency produced by any instrument (144Hz) therefore sample 'R' will show the most  perceptible induced vibration.

question: Question 185 The number of degrees of freedom of a planar linkage with 8 links and 9 simple revolute joints is
solution: No. of links: 1=8 No. of revolute joints, [latex] J=9[/latex] No. of higher pair, [latex] h=0[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Number of degree of freedom, [latex] \begin{aligned} n &=3(1-1)-2 J-h \\ &=3(8-1)-2 \times 9-0\\ \therefore \quad &=3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:

, the force acting along the line of action between the rack and the gear teeth is
solution: We known that [latex] \begin{aligned} P \cos \theta &=F \\ \therefore \quad P &=\frac{500}{\cos 20^{\circ}}=532 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 187 A compacting machine shown in the figure below is used to create a desired thrust force by using a rack and pinion arrangement. The input gear is mounted on the motor shaft. The gears have involutes teeth of 2 mm module. If the drive efficiency is 80%, the torque required on the input shaft to create 1000 N output thrust is
solution: Free body diagram [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 F&=1000\\ \text{or }F&=500 N\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Let [latex]T_{1} [/latex] be the torque applied by motor [latex] T_{2} [/latex] be the torque applied by gear [latex] \therefore [/latex] Power transmission [latex]=80 \% [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Now, } & T_{1} \omega{1}=\frac{2 T_{2}\omega_{2}}{0.8} \\ &=\frac{2 \times F \times\left(\frac{D}{2}\right)}{0.8} \times\left(\frac{\omega_{2}}{\omega_{1}}\right) \\ &=2 \times 500 \times \frac{0.16}{2} \times \frac{1}{0.8} \times \frac{1}{4} \\ &=25 \mathrm{Nm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 190 A mass M, of 20 kg is attached to the free end of a steel cantilever beam of length 1000 mm having a cross-section of 25 x 25 mm. Assume the mass of the cantilever to be negligible and  steel [latex]E_{steel}=200 GPa[/latex]
 . If the lateral vibration of this system is critically damped using a viscous damper, the damping constant of the damper is
solution: Moment of inertia of the shaft [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{1}{12} \times\left(25 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{4} \\ =3.25 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{m}^{4} \end{array}[/latex] Now, deflection at free end of cantilever beam [latex] \begin{array}{l} \delta=\frac{W L^{3}}{3 E I} \\ =\frac{20 \times 9.81 \times(1)^{3}}{3 \times 200 \times 10^{9} \times 3.25 \times 10^{-8}} \\ =0.01 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex] Now, we known that [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{g}{\delta}}=\sqrt{\frac{9.81}{0.01}} \\ &=31.32 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Critical damping constant [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{C} &=2 \mathrm{m} \omega_{n}=2 \times 20 \times 31.32 \\ & \approx 1250 \mathrm{Ns} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 191 A uniform stiff rod of length 300 mm and having a weight of 300 N is pivoted at one end and connected to a spring at the other end. For keeping the rod vertical ins a stable position the minimum value of spring constant K needed is
solution: Let the weight be displaced from equilibrium position, then For small displacement [latex] \theta=\frac{a}{300}=\frac{b}{150}[/latex] Taking moment about hinged point 'O' [latex] \begin{aligned} k . a .(0.3) &=w . b \\ \Rightarrow k .(0.3)^{2} &=300(0.150)\\ \therefore \quad k&=\frac{300 \times 0.150}{(0.30)^{2}}=500 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 192 The figure below shows a planar mechanism with single degree of freedom. The instant center 24 for the given configuration is located at a position
solution: Given planar mechanism has degree of freedom, N = 1 and two infinite parallel lines meet at infinity. So, the instantaneous centre [latex]I_{24}[/latex] will be at N , but for single degree of freedom, system moves only in one direction. Hence, [latex]I_{24}[/latex] is located at infinity [latex](\infty )[/latex].

question: Question 193 In the figure shown, the relative velocity of link 1 with respect to link 2 is 12 m/sec. Link 2 rotates at a constant speed of 120 rpm. The magnitude of Coriolis component of acceleration of link 1 is
solution: Velocity of link 1 with respect to 2 [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{1 / 2} &=12 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \omega &=\frac{2 \pi \mathrm{N}}{60}=\frac{2 \pi \times 120}{60} \\ &=12.566 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Corioli's component of acceleration [latex] \begin{aligned} &=2 V_{1 / 2} \omega=2 \times 12 \times 12.566 \\ &\approx 302 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 194 A vibrating machine is isolated from the floor using springs. If the ratio of excitation frequency of vibration of machine to the natural frequency of the isolation system is equal to 0.5, the transmissibility of ratio of isolation is
solution: Given [latex]\quad r=0.5[/latex] Due to isolation [latex] \xi_{S}=0[/latex] Transmissibility ratio [latex] \begin{aligned} T R &=\frac{\sqrt{1+(2 \xi r)^{2}}}{\sqrt{\left(1-r^{2}\right)^{2}+(2 \xi r)^{2}}} \\ &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\left(1-(0.5)^{2}\right)^{2}}} \\ &=\frac{1}{1-0.25}=\frac{4}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 196 A uniform rigid slenderbar of mass 10 kg, hinged at the left end is suspended with the help of spring and damper arrangement as shown in the figure where K = 2 kN/m, C = 500 Ns/m and the stiffness of the torsional spring [latex]K_{\theta }[/latex]
 is  1 kN/m/rad. Ignore the hinge dimensions. The damping coefficient in the vibration equation is given by
solution: Equivalent damping coefficient, [latex]C_{T}=80 \mathrm{Nms} / \mathrm{rad}[/latex]

question:
Question 197 A uniform rigid slenderbar of mass 10 kg, hinged at the left end is suspended with the help of spring and damper arrangement as shown in the figure where K = 2 kN/m, C = 500 Ns/m and the stiffness of the torsional spring [latex]K_{\theta }[/latex]
 is  1 kN/m/rad. Ignore the hinge dimensions. The un-damped natural frequency of oscillations of the bar about the hinge point is
solution: For small feflection, after equlibrium [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Now,}\quad \theta &=\frac{x_{1}}{0.4}=\frac{x_{2}}{0.5} \\ \therefore \quad x_{1} &=0.4\;\theta\\ \text{and}\quad x_{2}&=0.5\;\theta \end{aligned}[/latex] Moment of inertia [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{m l_{2}^{2}}{3}=\frac{10 \times(0.5)^{2}}{3} \\ =0.833 \mathrm{kgm}^{2} \end{array}[/latex] Now, from Newton's law of motion [latex] \begin{aligned} & c\dot{x}_{1} l_{1}+k x_{2} l_{2}+k_{\theta} \cdot \theta+I \ddot{\theta}=0 \\ &\Rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_{1}^{2} \dot{\theta}+\mathrm{k} l_{2}^{2} \theta+\mathrm{k}_{\theta} \cdot \theta+\mathrm{l} \ddot{\mathbf{\theta}}=0 \\ &\Rightarrow 500 \times(0.4)^{2} \dot{\theta}+\left(2000 \times(0.5)^{2}+1000\right) \theta \\ &+0.833 \ddot{\theta}=0\\ &\Rightarrow0.833\ddot{\theta}+80\dot{\theta}+1500\theta \qquad \cdots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Equation can be written as: [latex] \begin{aligned} I \ddot{\theta}+C_{T} \dot{\theta}+K_{T} \theta&=0\\ \therefore \qquad I&=0.833\\ C_{T}&=80 \\ K_{T}&=1500 \end{aligned}[/latex] Now natural frequency, [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{k_{T}}{I}}=\sqrt{\frac{1500}{0.833}} \\ &=42.43 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:

 and [latex]r_{B}[/latex]

solution: Acceleration of point B with respect to point A [latex] \begin{aligned} \overrightarrow{a_{B / A}} &=\vec{a}_{B}-\vec{a}_{A} \\ &=\overrightarrow{\omega^{2} r_{B}}-\overrightarrow{\omega^{2} r_{A}} \\ &=\omega^{2}\left(r_{B}-r_{A}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] in direction from Z to O

 and direction same as the direction of motion of point B

 and direction opposite to be direction of motion of point B
options.D:
[latex]\omega ^{2}(r_{B}-r_{A})[/latex]
 and direction from Z to O.

question: Question 200 A flexible rotor - shaft system comprises of a 10 kg rotor disc placed in the middle of a mass - less shaft of diameter 30mm and length 500 mm between bearing (shaft is being taken mass - less as the equivalent mass of the shaft is included in the rotor mass) mounted at the ends. The bearings are assumed to simulate simply supported boundary conditions. The shaft is made of steel for which the value of E is  [latex]2.1 \times 10^{11}[/latex]Pa.  What is the critical speed of rotation of the shaft?
solution: For shaft loaded at middle with mass M [latex] \text { Deflection: } \Delta=\frac{M g l^{3}}{48 E I}[/latex] Moment of inertia, [latex] \begin{aligned} I &=\frac{\pi}{64} d^{4}=\frac{\pi}{64} \times\left(30 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{4} \\ &=3.976 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{m}^{4} \end{aligned}[/latex] So; deflection of shaft, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Delta=\frac{M g l^{3}}{48 E I}=\frac{10 \times 9.81 \times\left(500 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{3}}{48 \times 2.1 \times 10^{11} \times 3.976 \times 10^{-8}}\\ =3.06 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{m} \\ \omega_{n}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{\Delta}}=\sqrt{\frac{9.81}{3.06 \times 10^{-5}}}=566.24 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{array}[/latex] Natural frequency, [latex] f_{n}=\frac{\omega_{n}}{2 \pi}=\frac{566.24}{2 \pi}=90.11 \mathrm{Hz}[/latex]

question: Question 201 For a certain engine having an average speed of 1200 rpm, a flywheel approximated as a solid disc, is required for keeping the fluctuation of speed within 2% about the average speed. The fluctuation of kinetic energy per cycle is found to be 2kJ. What is the least possible mass of the flywheel if its diameter is not to exceed 1m?
solution: Average speed, [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega &=\frac{2 \pi \times 1200}{60}=125.66 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \text{we know that}\\ \Delta E &=10^{2} \mathrm{C}_{S}\\ \text{and}\quad \Delta E &=\frac{M R^{2}}{2} \times \omega^{2} \times C_{S} \\ \therefore \quad M &=\frac{2 \Delta E}{R^{2} \times \omega^{2} \times C_{S}} \\ &=\frac{2 \times 2000}{\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2} \times(125.66)^{2} \times 0.02} \\ &=50.66\approx51 \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 202 When a cylinder is located in a Vee-block, then number of degrees of freedom which are arrested is
solution:
We clearly see that cylinder can either revolve about x-axis or
slide along x-axis and all the motions are restricted. Hence, Number of degrees of freedom = 2 and movability includes the six degrees of
freedom of the device as a whole, as the ground link were not fixed. So, 4 degrees
of freedom are constrained or arrested.

question: Question 203 Consider the arrangement shown in the figure below where J is the combined polar mass moment of inertia of the disc and the shafts. [latex]K_1,K_2,K_3[/latex] are the torsional stiffness of the respective shafts. The natural frequency of torsional oscillation  of the disc is given by
solution: Equivalent stiffness [latex] k_{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{k_{1} k_{2}}{k_{1}+k_{2}}+k_{3}=\frac{k_{1} k_{2}+k_{1} k_{3}+k_{2} k_{3}}{k_{1}+k_{2}}[/latex] Now natural frequency [latex] =\sqrt{\frac{k_{e q}}{J}}=\sqrt{\frac{k_{1} k_{2}+k_{1} k_{3}+k_{2} k_{3}}{J\left(k_{1}+k_{2}\right)}}[/latex]

question: Question 204 The lengths of the links of a 4-bar linkage with revolute pairs only are p,q,r and s units. Given that [latex]p \lt q \lt r \lt s[/latex]. Which of these links should be the fixed one, for obtaining a "double crank" mechanism?
solution:
Double crank mechanism is obtained when the 
shortest link is fixed. Here, the shortest link is p. 
Therefore link of length p should be fixed.

question: Question 205 The mechanism used in a shaping machine is
solution:
Crank and slotted lever mechanism is mostly used  
in shaping machines, which is the inversion of 
single slider-crank chain.

options.A: a closed 4-bar chain having 4 revolute pairs
options.B: a closed 6-bar chain having 6 revolute pairs
options.C: a closed 4-bar chain having 2 revolute and 2 sliding pairs
options.D: an inversion of the single slider-crank chain

Question 208 The assembly shown in the figure is composed of two massless rods of length l with two particles, each of mass m. the natural frequency of this assembly for small oscillations is
solution: [latex]I=m l^{2}+m l^{2}=2 m l^{2}[/latex] Considering moment equilibrium condition about axis of rotation. [latex] \begin{array}{l} 2 m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}+m g l \sin (\alpha+\theta)-m g l \sin (\alpha-\theta)=0 \\ \Rightarrow 2 m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}+m l g[\sin \alpha \cos \theta+\cos \alpha \sin \theta \\ \quad-\sin \alpha \cos \theta+\cos \alpha \cos \theta] \\ \Rightarrow 2 m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}+2 m g l \cos \alpha \sin \theta=0 \end{array}[/latex] For very small, [latex] \theta, \sin \theta \approx \theta [/latex] Hence, we get [latex] \begin{array}{c} 2 m l^{2} \ddot{\theta}+2 m g l \cos \alpha=0 \\ \omega=\sqrt{\frac{2 m g l \cos \alpha}{2 m l^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{g \cos \alpha}{l}} \end{array}[/latex]

Question 210 Which of the following statement is correct?

options.A: Flywheel reduces speed fluctuations during a cycle for a constant load, but flywheel does not control the mean speed of the engine if the load changes.
options.B: Flywheel does not reduce speed fluctuation during a cycle for a constant load, but flywheel does not control the mean speed of the engine if the load changes.
options.C: Governor controls speed fluctuations during a cycle for a constant load, but governor does not control the mean speed of the engine if the load changes.
options.D: Governor controls speed fluctuations during a cycle for a constant load, and governor also control the mean speed of the engine if the load changes.

question: Question 211 In the figure shown, the spring deflects by [latex]\delta[/latex] to position A ( the equilibrium position) when a mass m is kept on it. During free vibration, the mass is at position B at some instant. The change in potential energy of the spring-mass system from position A to position B is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta(P E) &=(P E)_{B}-(P E)_{A} \\ &=\frac{1}{2} k(x+\delta)^{2}+0-\left[\frac{1}{2} k \delta^{2}+m g x\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking reference datum at position B. At equilibrium position i.e., at A. [latex] \begin{array}{c} m g=\mathrm{k} \delta \\ \Delta(P E)=\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k \delta^{2}+x k \delta-\frac{1}{2} k \delta^{2}-m g x\\ \text{as }\quad m g=k \delta\\ \Delta(P E)=\frac{1}{2} k x^{2}+\frac{1}{2} k \delta^{2}+m g x-\frac{1}{2} k \delta^{2}-m g x\\ =\frac{1}{2} k x^{2} \end{array}[/latex]
